庵.mnemonic: While big (大) lightning (电) strikes outside, we take shelter (广) inside a HERMITAGE.

僕.mnemonic: 業 is kind of a cross between 業 and 美. It combines the “load of bricks” (北) from the former and big (大) from the latter, and will mean big servant. In the present entry, man (亻) and big servant combine to mean MANSERVANT. More commonly, this kanji is used by men as an informal first-person pronoun.

撲.mnemonic: The life of a sumo wrestler in many ways resembles that of a servant. He is forced to live in a “stable” under the control of his seniors and 親方 (おやかた, stable master), who preempts any cash prizes the wrestler may win. Here visualize a sumo bout: the hand (扌) DEALS A BLOW to a big servant (業, sumo wrestler).

叩.mnemonic: Images of a mouth before (口) and after (卩) being STRUCK (the one on the right has a split lower lip).

伐.mnemonic: Here man (亻) and spear (戈) combine to mean CUT DOWN. Learn to recognize this character by how it differs from the much more common 代. See the additional stroke here as a violent slashing action, CUTTING the man DOWN like a tree.

閥.mnemonic: The defining quality of CLIQUES and clans is their exclusivity, vividly represented here in a man's getting cut down (伐) trying to pass through a gate (門).

闘.mnemonic: Here we observe a FIGHT breaking out under a gate (門) between the pea-sized guy (豆, see ) and the 3-centimeter guy (寸, see ).

闇.mnemonic: Review 音 , which we took to mean not only SOUND but also the absence of light. Here the standing man blocks the sun from passing through the gate (門), so that it becomes DARK. Use the enclosing quality of 門 as a visual reminder of DARKNESS.

閑.mnemonic: Here we look in through a park gate (門), behind which a peaceful tree (木) bespeaks the LEISURE and QUIET inside.

脈.mnemonic: 月 suggests the category body part. At the right, picture ramifying VEINS with blood PULSING through them. Do not confuse the right-hand portion with 瓜. Also, note that the reading ミャク is unique in this course.

派.mnemonic: In the previous entry we saw VEINS branching out. Here we can see streams of water (氵) splitting off into different directions, symbolizing the emergence of SECTS or factions. M2 DISPATCH derives from the idea of being sent off in a given direction from a central location.

缶.mnemonic: Behold a CAN. S1 looks like an opened pull-tab top on a beverage CAN.

揺.mnemonic: hand +claw + can (S8-12): visualize as a bartender's two hands firmly holding a mixing can and SHAKING it. Note that when can appears with claw it loses its pull-tab top.

謡.mnemonic: Here a claw () keeps a beat on a can, while a mouth (part of 言) chants the words (言) of a POPULAR SONG.

遥.mnemonic: Here a claw loads cans onto a truck, to be transported somewhere FAR away.

陶.mnemonic: Think of taking clay from the hills (阝), then wrapping (勹) your hands around it to shape it into a can (缶, i.e., a pot): POTTERY.

陳.mnemonic: In the remainder of this course you will learn a number of characters that incorporate 東. The meaning EAST is not germane to these characters, so it is better to focus on the way 木 thoroughly penetrates 日, and thereby associate the grapheme 東 with the meaning all the way through or all the way across. In this entry, all the way through/across indicates a thorough description: SET FORTH/lay out. When you see this character, think of hiking to the top of the hills around the edge of town (阝) to get the “lay of the land,” a vantage point that SETS FORTH or lays out a panoramic view of (i.e., a view extending all the way across) the surrounding area.

陣.mnemonic: Here we observe a vehicle (車) driving into the hills around the edge of town (阝) to set up a strategic BATTLE FORMATION or CAMP.

陥.mnemonic: Here we can visualize the act of FALLING INTO. From high atop the hills around the edge of town (阝), an invading force peers down (S4-5) into the _old_ town (see 旧 0771) to plan its attack. It is about to FALL INTO a trap (visualize it FALLING INTO the empty space in the middle of 旧). Think of the reading おちいる (陥る、 fall into) as a combination of 落ちる (おちる, fall) and -入る (-いる, verbal suffix like “into” of “FALL INTO”). Think of 陥れる (おとしいれる) as a combination of 落とす (おとす, let fall, drop) and 入れる (いれる, put in).

隆.mnemonic: Just as 夂 has represented a rooftop, here it represents the top of a hill (阝). The top of the hill, in turn, represents not only geographic elevation, but also physical flourishing and material PROSPERITY. 生 _life/be born_ suggests the youthful RISE to physical flourishing and PROSPERITY.

降.mnemonic: Learn to recognize the meaning of this kanji by how it differs from the previous entry (and vice versa). Here the lower-right portion is a proxy for 年 year, indicating the decline of old age and contrasting with 生 above. After rising to the heights of vigor and PROSPERITY (隆), one in his later years may only DESCEND.

峰.mnemonic: Use the distinctive element 丰 as a cue for the meaning of the next four characters. Here visualize it as a path leading to the top of a high mountain (山) PEAK (the crossing strokes depict a series of steps). As in the previous two entries, 夂 represents the summit.

逢.mnemonic: Borrowing the idea of "path" from the previous entry, see 争 as a path or line moving forward (辶) to MEET someone or something. Note that all four kanji incorporating 争 are pronounced ホウ. This is another kanji that has not been officially simplified to 辶 (see 辻 1145). Remember, writing 辶 is always acceptable.

縫.mnemonic: This character subsumes the previous entry 逢 MEET. However, seeing 糸 thread, we should simply take 丰 as a needle and stitches, for SEWING. 辶 might be interpreted as the needle's forward motion, but in any case, learn to recognize SEWING from the combination of 糸 and 丰.

蜂.mnemonic: 虫 insect transforms 縫's needle and stitches into a wasp's stinger and stripes.

蜜.mnemonic: Recall 必 without fail (review 0549 if necessary). Let 宓 suggest crowded, from the idea that everyone must crowd together under one roof(), without fail. In this entry we thus have insects (虫) crowded inside a confining structure, to represent bees in a HONEYcomb.

密.mnemonic: (Continuing from the previous entry) Crowding (宓) inside a confined mountain (山) shelter: CLOSE/dense/tight. M2 SECRET derives from the idea of holding a piece of information CLOSE to one's chest.

秘.mnemonic: One's rice (禾) must be kept SECRET, without fail (必).

欧.mnemonic: Recall 区 0297 DIVIDE INTO SECTIONS/DISTRICTS. Here 欠 indicates the lack of such division. This we can easily associate with EUROPE, ever less divided since the advent of the European Union.

枢.mnemonic: Here visualize 区 as a board attached to the tree (木) by a hinge. Now imagine turning 区 left and right, like a hinged signboard, while 木 stays in place at one central point or PIVOT.

殴.mnemonic: Here let メ slash marks (see 殺 0522) suggest an image of violently BEATING/thrashing with a lance (殳).

駆.mnemonic: Here we find slash marks (メ) on a horse's hind. Picture a coachman DRIVING the horse forward with a violent crack of his whip.

馳.mnemonic: drive, ride... Recall 也 scorpion, first introduced at 地 0187. Here a horse, stung on the rear by a scorpion, breaks into a wild GALLOP.

騒.mnemonic: To raise a CLAMOR from the horse, dangle an insect(虫) from your hand (又) next to his rear.

旭.mnemonic: Behold the sun (日) coming up over the horizon: RISING SUN/morning sun. This appears mostly in personal and place names; the usual writing of あさひ (morning sun) is 朝日

旦.mnemonic: The sun (日) coming up over the horizon: DAWN. The readings タン and ダン sound like DAWN.

但.mnemonic: Used in writing the conditional conjunction 但し ただし (PROVIDED THAT). We might think of a man (亻) who was given the freedom to do whatever he pleased in the evening, PROVIDED he reported for duty promptly at dawn (旦).

担.mnemonic: The physical act of carrying something heavy on the shoulder, as a construction worker carries lumber, is not hard to see in this character for SHOULDERING. Take S8 as the thumb of a laborer's hand, laid over his SHOULDER to grasp the stack of two-by-fours (日) he is SHOULDERING.

亘.mnemonic: In 旦 1392 the bottom line represented the eastern horizon, where the sun appears at the beginning of the day. Here we add a second horizontal line, to indicate an arbitrary end point for a time period during which the sun (日) SPANS the distance between one horizontal line and the next. Try to think of it as a long distance/period.

恒.mnemonic: Mind (忄) + span (亘): let this suggest CONSTANCY of mood or temperament. Note, however, that this character does not refer to a mental state but merely the fact of being CONSTANT/ permanent.

垣.mnemonic: Visualize an earthen (土) wall spanning (亘) from the lower horizontal line to the upper horizontal line: FENCE/wall.

宣.mnemonic: To PROCLAIM is to announce something in public. Here we can think of span (亘) in the special sense of extending one's message across a wide area, as to every house (宀) in the land, in the manner of a television advertisement (see VI) or a house-by-house missionary campaign (see V2).

喧.mnemonic: Here we see a mouth (口) noisily uttering proclamations (宜): CLAMOROUS.

嘩.mnemonic: Review 華 1012. Here, picture words blooming forth from the mouth (口) like flowers: NOISY.

唾.mnemonic: Here, imagine SALIVA dangling (垂) down from the mouth (□). To remember the kun-yomi, think of all the つば in a tuba-player's mouthpiece.

壷.mnemonic: Now we add a つぼ for our つば: a JAR (spittoon?) for our spit. Picture the military man (士) aiming across the room to spit into this wide-bellied JAR/pot (resembling 亜). Note in the sample compounds that a spitting-pot is but one of many kinds of JARS or pots this character can refer to.

坪.mnemonic: A different kind of つぼ is the unit for 3.3 square meters, intuitively referred to here by the combination “flat (平) land(土)" (regardless of gradient, land for sale must be measured on a flat plane). If you don't remember how to distinguish 平 0334 and半 0335, now would be a good time to review.

畔.mnemonic: Here we observe a rice field (田) alongside a body of water. Half(半) of the rice field is on the WATERSIDE (the right-hand half, as pictured here).

衆.mnemonic: The lower portion of this character resembles the right-hand portion of 脈. Here, imagine blood (血) “multiplying” along many branching bloodlines, as a single ancestor proliferates into a vast MULTITUDE.

伊.mnemonic: Visualize as a three-fingered hand grasping a staff (S6). Here picture it using the staff to trace the katakana letter イ, which was in fact derived from this kanji. 伊 is used to represent the sound イ in kanji-based phonetic spellings, and as an abbreviation for Italy.

君.mnemonic: (Continuing from the previous entry) The hand wields the staff of authority (S4); the mouth (□) issues official orders: RULER.

群.mnemonic: Here we observe a flock of sheep (羊) following their ruler (君, the shepherd, who holds a shepherd's staff): flock/crowd/GROUP.

郡.mnemonic: Ruler(君)+town(B). This suggests the ruler of an area centered on a major town: a count. A count rules over a COUNTY.

那.mnemonic: It suffices to distinguish this character from the ones before and after it, and to note its use in V1, which you should practice writing out and pronouncing.

邦.mnemonic: Think of S1-4 as a fence or palisade. Together with B walls around the edge of town, this suggests the boundaries around the territory of an independent political entity, or STATE. M2 is an extended meaning.

郊.mnemonic: Crossing(交) the walls around the edge of town (B) takes you into the SUBURBS. Note that, except for 較 0693, all kanji incorporating 交 follow its on reading, コウ、

効.mnemonic: Crossing/interchanging (交) + strengths (力). Informed by the economic theory of comparative advantage, we can derive the idea of EFFECTIVENESS from the way this character implies "exchanging strength with strength," each individual doing what he or she does with the greatest EFFECT.

絞.mnemonic: Imagine either end of a rope (糸) looping around someone’s neck and then crossing (交): STRANGLE; WRING. As a shortcut, visualize S11-12 as the two ends of the rope closing around the neck. Do not confuse 絞る (しぼる, wring) with 縛る(しばる, bind; see 0984), or 搾る (しぼる, squeeze, extract; see next entry).

搾.mnemonic: Imagine you are trying to extract a painful splinter from your hand: first you saw (乍) a hole (穴) in your hand (扌), then you SQUEEZE out the splinter. Now practice writing and distinguishing the meanings of the three verbs listed at the end of the previous entry.

紋.mnemonic: Thread (糸) + writing (文): indicates the distinctive insignia “written” in thread on a flag, uniform, etc.—a CREST.

菊.mnemonic: The variety of CHRYSANTHEMUM most often seen in Japan is a large, tufty flower. In this kanji, 米 represents the flower's long, tightly gathered petals, while 勹 suggests its elephantine size, and + implies plant. Note that the chrysanthemum is used in the Japanese Imperial Seal, and that the on reading キク is unique in this course.

帝.mnemonic: Visualize the EMPEROR, wearing a special ceremonial belt (S5-6) and cloth gown (巾).

締.mnemonic: Here let 糸 cord represent the cords of the emperor (帝)'s belt (S11-12). Now visualize the cords of his belt TIGHTENING, symbolic of the uncompromising restrictions on his public and private behavior. M2 contract/CONCLUDE is an extended meaning.

諦.mnemonic: Building on the previous entry, now visualize the emperor, weary of living under such tight constraints, announcing (言) his abdication: "I GIVE UP."

享.mnemonic: Means ENJOY in the sense of receiving something beneficial. Here we see the child (子) receive the benefit of some additional height (from 高 0185). Now think of the hardships you suffered when you were small, and all the benefits you ENJOYED once you grew tall. As a grapheme, 享 will mean growing child.

郭.mnemonic: Here we observe the growing child (享) trying unsuccessfully to scale the walls around the edge of town (阝): OUTER ENCLOSURE.

亭.mnemonic: Recall that 丁 0437 depicts a T-shaped intersection, and that 高 0185 depicts a tall building. Now visualize in this character a tall INN/restaurant situated at a T-shaped intersection.

停.mnemonic: Picture a man (亻) STOPPING at the T-shaped intersection where the tall inn (亭) is located.

昆.mnemonic: Visualize 比 as a pair of INSECTS buzzing about on a sunny(日) day.

混.mnemonic: Now picture the insects (昆) MIXING (reproducing) in water(氵).

皆.mnemonic: Take 白 as a variant of 自 (indicating one's self), and the pair of seated people (比) as a pair of one's fellows. ALL three are gathered together.

楷.mnemonic: Refers to the BLOCK CHARACTER STYLE used in printing and non-cursive writing, in which all (皆) characters are written with the regular straightness of a tree (木). Note that all three characters incorporating 皆 follow its on reading, カイ.

諧.mnemonic: All (皆) words (言) in agreement: HARMONY.

階.mnemonic: See ß as calling attention to the two levels in 皆 1427: its upper bulge points to the upper FLOOR/story occupied by one's two friends (比); its lower bulge points to the lower FLOOR/story occupied by one's self (白). M2 RANK/class is an extended meaning.

陛.mnemonic: As in the previous entry, let ß suggest different levels. At the top we find a pair of seated people (比), here representing the emperor and empress. Now picture their Highnesses descending the IMPERIAL PALACE STEPS toward the ground (土). Learn to recognize this kanji and the ones before and after it by how they differ.

陸.mnemonic: Review 先 0134. In the next few entries, the grapheme 圭 draws our attention to the substrate of earth (土) situated beneath 先's roots. We'll call it earth's crust (not to be confused with 圭). To signify LAND (in the sense of “not the sea”), we take earth's crust and add hills (B). The reading リク is unique in this course.

睦.mnemonic: This character represents the idea of intimate familiarity: an eye (日) sees all the way down below the roots and into the earth's crust (圭): intimate/FRIENDLY.

勢.mnemonic: earth's crust and 丸 round together make 執 the round earth. This kanji illustrates the idea of POWER by showing 力 power carrying the whole round earth on its back. Associate MI POWER with M2 CONDITION/trend via the idea of the current state of one's strength. Now go back and peek at the old form of 芸.

熱.mnemonic: Below the round earth (勢) a fire (灬) burns: the earth's HOT core. The reading ネツ is unique in this course.

熟.mnemonic: 享 (growing child) and 丸 (round) together make 孰 (well-rounded child). To this add a low flame (灬), for tempering: MATURE.

塾.mnemonic: Here 士 shifts our attention to the place where the well-rounded child (孰) develops: PRIVATE SCHOOL.

陵.mnemonic: Only 夂 distinguishes this kanji from 陸, so focus on that. Imagine that emperors are buried with crossed legs (夂), just as the Egyptian pharaohs were buried with crossed arms. Thus a hill (B, i.e., a tumulus) where one finds crossed legs buried beneath the roots (凌) could only be an IMPERIAL MAUSOLEUM.

菱.mnemonic: We know not to confuse this character with 陵 1438 IMPERIAL MAUSOLEUM because it has no hill (B) under which to inter an emperor. We thus turn our attention to its shape—wide at the center and narrow at top and bottom—which suggests a RHOMBUS ◇.

俊.mnemonic: Review 酸 0800. Here, we have a “sharply stimulating” (夋) person (亻): BRILLIANT PERSON.

唆.mnemonic: A mouth (口) giving a sharp stimulus (夋), that is, INSTIGATING someone to do something.

筈.mnemonic: Originally this meant “notch of an arrow,” but it is mainly used today to express the idea “TO BE EXPECTED.” Recalling the ancient use of bamboo for keeping records and figures, picture the tongue (舌) pronouncing a figure tallied on bamboo (*), indicating it as one’s estimate, as the EXPECTED figure.

箸.mnemonic: Here a person (者) uses bamboo (^^) as an instrument for eating or serving: a pair of CHOPSTICKS. The final dot stroke, just above 日, appears in 者-based kanji that have not officially been simplified (including 賭 and 儲, just below). As the variant forms indicate, you will also see these kanji written without this final stroke.

暑.mnemonic: The HOT summer sun (日) scorches this hapless person (者). Alternatively, see an elder (耂) being scorched between two HOT summer suns. Though the on-yomi of 者 0107 is シャ, most kanji incorporating it on the bottom or right side (as here and in the following entries) are read チョ or ショ, and all have the short vowel.

署.mnemonic: Review 憲 0417, where we added the meaning law for 罒. Here see a person (者) inside a GOVERNMENT OFFICE, such as a city office or police station. The “wide net of the law” covers him; that is, he is under legal authority. For M2, note that SIGNING ONE'S NAME puts a person under legal obligation.

曙.mnemonic: Think of a government office (署) near where you live, such as a police station or fire station. Someone is on duty there around the clock—even when the sun (日)'s first rays shine upon it at DAWN, as depicted here.

賭.mnemonic: Here we observe a person (者) presenting money (貝) as a WAGER.

諸.mnemonic: Words (言) + people (者): let this combination suggest the VARIOUS languages people speak.

儲.mnemonic: Visualize two persons (亻 and 者) exchanging words (言) in negotiating a sweet deal: PROFIT.

緒.mnemonic: Visualize the person (者) reaching down and taking the near end of the thread (that is, its beginning or OUTSET), and then following the thread right down the LINE, like a detective following a thread of events. It helps to visualize S10 as the LINE or thread of events being followed.

翁.mnemonic: Recall 羽 wings. Ignore 公's meaning and instead visualize it as a weary OLD MAN spreading his angel wings (S1-2) as he prepares to fly up toward heaven.

婆.mnemonic: A woman (女) pounded many times by the waves (波) of aging: OLD WOMAN. As you begin this set of kanji that incorporate 女 at the bottom, it would be a good idea to review the ones you have already seen:

姿.mnemonic: Woman(女) + next/secondary(次): visualize 次 as the “secondary” appearance of the woman, that is, her shadow cast across the floor. In this way let 次 visually represent the outline of the woman's form: her FIGURE or posture.

恣.mnemonic: Mind (心) + next/secondary (次): let this suggest a person who immediately follows through on whatever idea occurs to him: ARBITRARY. Note the slight difference between the top portions of this entry and the last one. We shall treat both forms as 次.

妄.mnemonic: Here 亡 does not suggest a deceased woman, but rather a demented one: RASH/outrageous.

萎.mnemonic: Distinguished from 委 0396 by the extra grass (+++) piled on top of rice (禾), causing 女 to WILT visibly under the additional load.

妻.mnemonic: Review 婦 1017. Here, visualize a woman holding a broom: WIFE.

凄.mnemonic: Imagine a TREMENDOUS, terrible wife (妻) who is as cold as ice (冫).

章.mnemonic: Imagine the sound (音) of a needle (+) (see 針 0556) bobbing in and out of a slave's forehead, marking him with a tattoo. This kanji ultimately derives from that barbaric act of inscribing a person with a distinguishing mark or BADGE, which later became associated with the idea of writing and, by extension, CHAPTER.

彰.mnemonic: Here visualize 彡 as a three-striped badge, like that worn by military officers of a certain rank. The purpose of the three-striped badge, like any military decoration, is to PROCLAIM the officer's MERITS. See 顕 1921 for an additional sample compound. Note that both kanji incorporating 章 follow its on reading, ショウ、

障.mnemonic: A man in Colombia once operated a mobile library called the Biblioburro using two donkeys-Alfa and Beto. In this character, imagine Alfa and Beto trying to deliver the next chapter (章) of a serial novel to an isolated village located on the other side of the hills (B). The hills present a HINDRANCE to the chapter's progress.

辛.mnemonic: The poor standing man (立) undergoes the HARD and painful ordeal of standing directly on a needle (+)(note how this differs from 章 above). The pain he feels in his feet is comparable to the sharp pain we feel in our mouths when we eat PUNGENT or spicy foods. As a grapheme, 辛 will generally go by the label pain.

宰.mnemonic: The idea of PRESIDING (over) or managing is represented here in the act of keeping a roof (宀) over (i.e., managing) a situation that is inherently hard (辛) on those involved. See expressions of protest coming from 辛 but the roof keeping the situation under control.

辣.mnemonic: A bundle (束) of spicy (辛) hot peppers: SHARP. The reading ラツ is unique in this course.

辞.mnemonic: Here let 辛 hard/painful suggest “difficult.” Now, no movement humans make is so difficult as the movements of the tongue (舌) in producing WORDS. After many years of such painstaking WORD-uttering, one naturally wants to RESIGN and rest one’s tongue in a quiet retirement.

壁.mnemonic: Take 辟 to mean criminal, represented by the idea of pain (辛) attempting to enter one’s home through a door (户) or other opening (口) (be careful to distinguish this from 辞 above). In the present entry, we observe a criminal jumping over an earthen (土) WALL.

璧.mnemonic: (Continuing from the previous entry) Having scaled the wall, the criminal (辟) immediately looks for the house gems (玉). Here he sets his sights on a MAGNIFICENT JEWEL.

癖.mnemonic: Disease (疒) and criminal (辟) combine to suggest bad HABITS.

避.mnemonic: Here we send a criminal (辟) away on a truck (辶) so that we won't run into him anymore:

幸.mnemonic: S4-8 are an abbreviated version of 羊 sheep (therefore, the final two strokes do not represent a needle, as in the preceding entries). We thus have the “land (土) of the sheep,” a place of rolling green hills of GOOD FORTUNE and HAPPINESS.

服.mnemonic: Here visualize 月 as two high shelves for storing one's folded clothes (this shelf image for 月 will prove useful again later). Take S5-6 as a coat rack, and S7-8 as the coats that hang from it. Now imagine a SUBMISSIVE partner putting away one's CLOTHES on these apparatuses.

報.mnemonic: Happiness (幸) + coat rack (艮). Imagine a happy working woman or man returning home and handing their coat to their partner, who then hangs it on the coat rack (the idea to take from this image is that of reciprocal action). The two partners REPORT the day's news to each other, and REQUITE each other's love.

執.keywords: EXECUTE, perform, SEIZE, hold fast to
執.mnemonic: Happiness (幸) + round (丸): here we might imagine a scene in which an eager child happily SEIZES a round ball. Connect this with M1 by thinking of performing or EXECUTING the seizing action.

摯.mnemonic: To seize (執) a person's hand (手) in a handshake is a sign of SINCERITY.

達.mnemonic: We continue with happy (幸), but now give the sheep (羊) its full allotment of three horizontal strokes. Here, think of how happy a truck (辶) driver feels when he finally reaches/ ATTAINS his destination. The secondary meaning deliver can be thought of as "making (something) reach" its destination.

朗.mnemonic: A good (良) moon (月) is CLEAR and bright. Associate the image with M1 CHEERFUL via the idea of brightness.

浪.mnemonic: Stagnant water tends to be unclean. Thus “good”(良) water (氵) is water that does not stay in one place, but ROAMS/drifts about. The connection with M1 is that a BILLOW (a large wave) ROAMS across the water. The reading ロウ sounds like ROAM.

呉.keywords: KINGDOM OF WU, GIVE; do for (someone)
呉.mnemonic: Refers to historical Chinese states in the region around modern Shanghai. For the purpose of reading Japanese, our main goal is to give this a grapheme meaning for use in the next two entries: visualize a person typing at a keyboard. Note that while 虞 2001 has no on-yomi, the others based on 呉 are pronounced ゴ、号 0300

娯.mnemonic: Visualize a woman (女) ENJOYING herself as she types at a keyboard (呉).

富.mnemonic: Visualize 吕 as a covered grain silo located next to a rice field. The present entry expresses the idea of wealth by putting an entire grain silo under one roof (*): RICH.

副.mnemonic: Here we slice (刂) the grain silo (吕)'s original supply of grain into subordinate or SECONDARY portions. Note that the three kanji in which 吕 appears at one side (rather than in the center, as in 富) have the on reading フク.

幅.mnemonic: Think of how WIDE a cloth (巾) you would need to cover the entire grain silo (吕).

福.mnemonic: God (ネ) filling the grain silo (吕): good FORTUNE.

祉.mnemonic: When God “remembered” Noah, He stopped the rains and promised never again to flood the earth. In this way “God (ネ) + stop (止)” signifies BLESSEDNESS.

禍.mnemonic: Review 過 0464. Unlike the previous entry, here God (ネ) does not stop (止) but continues “piling it on” to the point of excess (問), causing a CALAMITY. Note that all characters incorporating 問 are pronounced カ.

渦.mnemonic: Water (氵) + excessive (問) (in this case, excessive energy): WHIRLPOOL. A shortcut is to see 問 as a pair of eddies.

鍋.mnemonic: Recalling the excessively tall stack of boxes in 過 0464, here visualize an excessively tall pile of metal (金) POTS and pans in one's sink.

蘭.mnemonic: Memorize the reading ラン for the next two entries, which differ only by ++ and 木. With so few kanji pronounced ラン, it's easy to associate ラン with HOLLAND (オランダ, once written 阿蘭陀 or 和蘭), and by extension with ORCHID. Remember that of these two kanji, the one with ++ (suggesting plant species) refers to ORCHID, and thus also to HOLLAND.

欄.mnemonic: (Continuing from the previous entry) Here, 木 resembles a long newspaper COLUMN running along the side of a crowded page.

潤.mnemonic: Here we look in through the gates (門) of the king (王)'s palace toward his garden. To keep his garden MOIST, the king fills luxuriant fountains and pools with water (氵).

淵.mnemonic: Review 片 0922. Here, picture trees lining either EDGE of a DEEP POOL. An image search for 千鳥ヶ淵 (ちどりがふち, an imperial palace moat lined with cherry trees) will no doubt turn up photos to help vivify the image.

滑.mnemonic: Review 骨 0465 if necessary. Here water (Y) slips and SLIDES SMOOTHLY along bone.

稽.mnemonic: For this character, you need only concern yourself with learning the compounds 稽古 (けい こ) and 滑稽な (こっけいな).

肩.mnemonic: 戸 frames the top of this character the way the collarbone frames the top of the torso. Visualize S2-3 as the collarbone, S4 as the upper arm extending down from it, and 月 as the flesh protected underneath the SHOULDER. You might visualize S1 as an epaulet.

脅.mnemonic: Three powerful predators (筋) THREATEN their prey. They regard it only as flesh (月).

肯.mnemonic: Imagine the moon (月) giving its ASSENT for some visitors to stop (止) on it for awhile.

双.mnemonic: A pair of hands: SET OF TWO/pair.

江.mnemonic: Visualize the water (氵) flowing into the open space at the left side of 工, which graphically represents an indented seashore, or INLET.

湾.mnemonic: The next two kanji are similar in appearance and meaning. Use 弓 and 己 to distinguish BAY (here) from PORT (below). To visualize BAY, let 弓 suggest a bow-shaped curve in the coastline embracing the waters of the sea (the secondary meaning curve appears in the word 湾曲 [わんきょく, curve]). Note how 亦 shortens the old form.

港.mnemonic: Continuing from the previous entry) Recall how can mean wrap/roll up (see包 0457 if necessary). Here, it refers to the way in which ships are "wrapped up" together (共) inside the breakwaters () of a PORT. Remember, bow (弓) represents the curved outline of a BAY (湾), whereas wrap up (2) signals the full enclosure of a PORT.洪0358,湾 1500

選.mnemonic: Here let represent a shopping cart. To perceive the idea of SELECTING, visualize a pair of wrapped(己) items (packages) SELECTED from the shelves and placed together(共) in the shopping cart.遷0785

択.mnemonic: Review 尺0337 and 駅0339 (as with the latter, 尺 digger abbreviates 睪 in the old forms of the next several entries). Here the digger must SELECT which hand (扌) to shovel with.

沢.mnemonic: 氵 signals that water gushes forth after the digger(尺) sinks his shovel into the earth: SWAMP. Associate this with M2 ABUNDANT by thinking of the water "overflowing." The meaning SWAMP sounds a bit like “さわ-mpu.”沼1105

訳.mnemonic: Here we observe a words (言)-digger (尺), or TRANSLATOR. His job is to bring the SENSE or meaning of foreign words to light.

釈.mnemonic: Review 番 0299. Here, imagine the digger (尺) unearthing and RELEASING a buried cache of crudely tied rice bundles. Link this with M2 ELUCIDATE via the idea of RELEASING clarifying details.

敷.mnemonic: Review 専 0580. Also, see the note at 簿 0985 about the extra dot stroke at the top. Here, we can visualize the rod-holding hand (攵) LAYING a large mixing cauldron upon the shoulders of this small person(方).

傲.mnemonic: Take 敖 as an abbreviated version of the previous entry, then visualize the small person (方) PROUDLY carrying the load laid upon him. Let 亻 therefore suggest manly PRIDE. This kanji mostly appears in 傲慢, so focus your efforts on learning that compound.

贅.mnemonic: Informed by the previous two entries, visualize laying heaps of money (貝) upon the small person(方): LUXURY.

審.mnemonic: Review 番 0299 WATCH. Here let “roof (宀) + watch” suggest a sentry or other official carefully questioning a suspect in the privacy of an interrogation room: EXAMINE CAREFULLY.

藩.mnemonic: In feudal Japan, each lord was allotted a DOMAIN endowed with an adequate supply of arable land (here represented by ++), water (氵), and armed men to watch over it (番).

翻.keywords: TURN OVER, RENDER IN ANOTHER FORM, translate
翻.mnemonic: Recall from 番 0299 the idea of taking turns or rotating. With 羽 here, we thus get an image of the “alternating” up and down motion of a bird’s wings: TURN OVER. With this image of TURNING OVER we can easily associate the idea of RENDERING IN ANOTHER FORM, such as translating a document from one language into another.

翔.mnemonic: A winged(羽) goat(羊) taking off: SOAR.

査.mnemonic: Picture climbing up the ladder (且) into the tree (木) to LOOK INTO something.

租.mnemonic: In ancient China LAND TAXES were paid in kind, such as in neatly bundled rice stalks (禾). The ladder (且.) suggests a progressive scale of taxation. Recall that kanji in which 且 appears at the right are pronounced ソ、

粗.mnemonic: Learn to recognize this kanji by how it differs from the previous entry. Compared to the neat rice bundle (禾) used for LAND TAX, the "ordinary" rice bundle (*) in this kanji seems COARSE.

阻.mnemonic: Visualize climbing the ladder(日) to see over the top of the hills (阝), which HAMPER (i.e., obstruct) the view.

狙.mnemonic: An ambitious dog(犭) who AIMS to climb the social ladder(日).

宜.mnemonic: Climbing a ladder (日) is the RIGHT/most suitable method for getting on top of a roof (宀).

畳.mnemonic: Visualize 田 as four adjoining TATAMI MATS. To save space when storing, we FOLD them UP in a ladder (日)-like stack.

甲.mnemonic: Visualize 日 as a protective SHELL (S5 provides a vertical dimension so that we can see the SHELL as being “on top,” where it can cover underlying soft tissue). Now if you memorize V3, you will know this kanji like the back of your hand. For M2 FIRST IN A SERIES, see the note at

乙.mnemonic: By visualizing this as an oddly written numeral 2, it is easy to remember the meaning SECOND IN A SERIES. Just as this character roughly approximates the numeral 2, its pronunciation vaguely resembles the word “two”: オツ. No other kanji in this course has the reading オツ.

丙.mnemonic: We have seen this form before, inside 病 0617. By itself it is the kanji for THIRD IN A SERIES. In the context of a series, we can remember that 丙 represents the THIRD element by discerning a downward-facing numeral 3 in the lower portion. Similarly, we can discern a numeral 2 in 乙 and a numeral 1 inside 甲. Practice writing and saying V2.

柄.mnemonic: 丙 here works like a device to measure the tree (木)’s CHARACTER and STATUS. The top of 丙 (S5 here) is used to measure the tree’s height (that is, its stature or STATUS). The rest of 丙 (内, inside) measures what the tree has inside (that is, its CHARACTER). M3 HANDLE is easily recognized in S5.

押.mnemonic: Learn the next two entries by how they differ. Here, 日 has risen too high, so the hand (扌) needs to press it down: PUSH.

抽.mnemonic: (Continuing from the previous entry) Here, 日 has dropped too low, so the hand needs to pull it up: DRAW OUT.

捜.mnemonic: Here you can visualize LOOKING FOR an object in the dark with the dim light of a torch. With your left hand (扌) you feel for the object; with your right hand (又) you carry a torch (申).

届.mnemonic: Visualize 由 as a DELIVERY person reaching up with one hand to knock on someone's door. M1 DELIVER and M2 REACH should not be thought of as separate meanings, but rather as transitive and intransitive senses of the same action.

宙.mnemonic: Try to see this as the lid of a box flying into MIDAIR. Visualize 由 as a box with a rod that rises up from the inside and pushes the “roof” (一, i.e., lid) of the box into MIDAIR, in the same way that a rocket sends a spacecraft into SPACE. See 宇 1542 for compounds using M1.

笛.mnemonic: In the previous entry I asked you to visualize the central vertical stroke as a rod rising up out of a box. Here see it as air rising up through holes in a bamboo (竹) instrument—a FLUTE or whistle.

袖.mnemonic: ネ indicates clothing. Here visualize 由 as a SLEEVE with a wrist poking out of it. 裾 1534

襟.mnemonic: Clothing (⻂) + prohibition (禁): a priest’s COLLAR. The on-yomi follows 禁 0312 キン. Interchangeable with the next entry.

衿.mnemonic: Again 礻 indicates clothing. Visualize the lower portion of S9 as a stiff COLLAR rising from the back of a man's neck (we're looking at him from the side). Interchangeable with the previous entry.

裾.mnemonic: 袖 1531 depicts a SLEEVE with a wrist poking out of it. Here, visualize the rectangular shape in 戶 as the CUFF or hem at the end of a sleeve.

据.mnemonic: Here imagine the hand (扌) SETTING something in place inside the residence (居).

握.mnemonic: Here imagine the hand (扌) GRASPING/seizing an item in a small shop (屋). Remember, in the small shop the hand GRASPS (握); in the residence it SETS (据).

揃.mnemonic: Visualize the hand (扌) putting in order the items before (前) it: MAKE UNIFORM. The head character is shown with the old form of 月, reflecting the fact that this name-use list kanji has not officially been standardized (as of this writing). Either way of writing the character is acceptable.

撫.mnemonic: Here the hand (扌) turns aches and pains to nothing (無): STROKE/soothe.

託.mnemonic: Visualize 乇 as a person sitting on the floor with his arms outstretched, relaxing. The picture in this entry is of a person giving words (言) of instruction to a subordinate so that he can unburden himself of (i.e., ENTRUST) a responsibility, and then be at leisure.

宅.mnemonic: A person relaxing (乇) in the comfort of his home (宀): DWELLING HOUSE.

詫.mnemonic: Words (言) of APOLOGY delivered personally at the home (宅) of the offended.

宇.mnemonic: Note how 于 here differs from 乇 above. We can still picture it as a person spreading his arms widely, only now he is not seated but standing. Here we observe him gazing up at the roof (宀) over the world (i.e., the firmament): UNIVERSE.

芋.mnemonic: With a slight variation in strokes we move from the cosmic to the most literally terrestrial. Here picture a rhizome spreading its roots widely inside the earth, under a grass (艹) covering: POTATO. Practice identifying the meanings of these last two kanji from the variable component.

寿.mnemonic: Here 寸 outstretched arm holds a long rod (S4), like an elderly man steadying himself on a staff. We add a crossing stroke to the staff for each stage of life completed (childhood, youth, and middle age), so that the staff represents the attainment of LONGEVITY. His attainment is cause for CONGRATULATIONS.

鋳.mnemonic: Giving a long-lived (寿) shape to metal (金): CAST/mint. 銭

銘.mnemonic: Etching one's name (名) in metal (金): INSCRIBE.

鏡.mnemonic: Ancient mirrors were made not of glass but of metal (金). If we take S14-19 as a variant of 見 see, we obtain an image of someone standing (立) before a metal object and seeing his image: MIRROR. M2 is an extended meaning. Distinguish the right half of this character from the two halves of 競

境.mnemonic: Suggests standing (立) in a high position from which a wide area (土) can be seen (S9-14). No doubt this originally referred to a border lookout (like one of the towers along the Great Wall), since this kanji means BOUNDARY. The kanji for BOUNDARIES can also signify SITUATION, in the sense of the circumstances that surround us.

環.mnemonic: I suggests gem or round object. Here we might imagine S10 as a RING, seen edgewise, resting on a velvet cloth stand (see 園 0856) and covered by a protective netting (四). M2 is a logical extension of M1.

還.mnemonic: RETURNING a ring (from the previous entry) to its sender.

盾.mnemonic: Picture this as a soldier sheltering himself underneath a SHIELD.

循.mnemonic: Since the shield (盾) cannot be penetrated, the only choice is to go (彳) around it (S1-2 indicate a path around the top). Let this image of “going around” suggest the idea of CIRCULATING.

巡.mnemonic: Resembles one of those mobile signs used by highway maintenance crews in which a series of arrows (<<<) flashes in sequence, directing traffic to go around.

這.mnemonic: Focus on how the strokes of 言 lie flat, keeping a low profile as they move forward (辶) along the ground: CRAWL. As ever, 辶 may be replaced by 辶.

逓.mnemonic: At 巡 1553 I suggested you visualize <<< as a set of flashing arrows. Here I suggest you visualize the parallel horizontal lines (S3-4) on this truck (辶)'s cargo as a sign directing us to keep the cargo moving forward on its way; i.e., to RELAY it forward on the next stage of its journey.

息.mnemonic: Through the nose (自) and down to the heart (心) passes the BREATH of life. Review 自 if the connection with nose is not clear. 憩1557, 鼻1558,臭1560

憩.mnemonic: Catching one's breath (息) and taking refreshment for one's tongue (舌): TAKE A REST.

鼻.mnemonic: The character for NOSE starts with the grapheme nose (自), to which is attached a head (田), into which are inhaled two streams of air (H), one through each nostril (ignore earlier meanings established for 廾).

孔.mnemonic: Associate child (子) + sharp hook (L) with the predictable result of such a combination: OPEN HOLE.

臭.mnemonic: In the next five entries we should interpret 大 visually, although its semantic value big can reinforce each image. In all five, see 大's slanting strokes coming together into a vertex that points into the element above it. Here, we observe a (big) odor converging on one's nose (自): BAD SMELL.

嗅.mnemonic: To the previous entry we add 口 to suggest the sensory perception of a bad smell (臭), that is, the act of SMELLING or sniffing. This character incorporates the old form of the previous entry, which is based on 犬 rather than 大. 嗅 was not officially standardized to match 臭 when it was added to the Joyo list.

奥.mnemonic: Here visualize two blitzing columns converging on the INNER PART of a property, where the rice (米) is stored.

尖.mnemonic: Here the slanting strokes of 大 taper to a (small 小) POINTY tip. Big at the base, but very small at the tip. This kanji is now often replaced in on-yomi compounds by 先.

突.mnemonic: Recall 穴 hole. Now see 大 THRUSTING upward into the hole.

窒.mnemonic: (Continuing from the previous entry) Now see 至 arriving at and plugging up/CHOKING OFF the hole in 穴. CHOKE relates in a meaningful way to M2 NITROGEN, whose gaseous form has been called the "lifeless air," for in it flames expire and men suffocate.

窃.mnemonic: Imagine a thief cutting (切) a hole (穴) in your bag to STEAL your valuables.

衝.mnemonic: Review 行 0055. Here, imagine cars speeding down the two intersecting roads and COLLIDING "heavily" (重) into each other.

契.mnemonic: Here try to visualize the idea of a man's fulfilling his PLEDGE to provide for his family. The (big) man carries a machete (刀, sword) over one shoulder and a growing plant (representing grain) over the other.

喫.mnemonic: (Continuing from the previous entry) After the man fulfills his pledge (契) by providing grain, a mouth (□) INGESTS it.

潔.mnemonic: From the growing plants the man gathered in 1568, we now produce IMMACULATE thread: take the raw growing plant at the top (S4-7), then scrape off the dirt with a knife (刀) and rinse with water (氵) to produce IMMACULATE thread (糸), issuing from the bottom.

侮.mnemonic: Calling (or considering) someone merely an everyman (每 every + 亻 man): INSULT/disdain.

梅.mnemonic: A tree (木) for every (毎) purpose, the ume is planted for its celebrated late-winter flowers but also for its fruit, which are used not only as fruit but also for pickles, sauce, liquor, and medicine. For its early summer ripening it gives its name to the East Asian rainy season (see V2).

悔.mnemonic: Here think of 毎 every in the sense of “all possible.” In this way let “heart (忄) + all possible” suggest wholehearted REPENTANCE/regret.

敏.mnemonic: As in the previous entry, think of 毎 every in the sense of "all possible." With 攵, we can imagine a striking action performed with the greatest possible agility: NIMBLE.

繁.mnemonic: As with 潔 several entries back, we can visualize thread issuing forth as it is produced. Here a nimble (敏) spinner quickly produces large quantities of thread (糸), an intuitive image for the concepts THRIVE, be busy, numerous, and manifold.

繋.mnemonic: Imagine tying the lances (殳) to the car (車) with rope (糸): CONNECT/tie together. This character is often replaced by 係 in on-yomi compounds.

茂.mnemonic: Imagine using the blade at the end of this guided spear(戊) to slice your way through a thicket of tall grass (艹): GROW THICK.

橋.mnemonic: 喬, like 高 means tall. In ancient China, as today, bridges were among the tallest structures. The character they created for BRIDGE, then, implied a tall structure made of wood(木). Note that this character contains 夭, not 天; S5 must be written from right to left.

矯.mnemonic: Tall(喬) + arrow(矢). Here the arrow has been stretched tall to make it as straight and narrow as possible: RECTIFY.

稿.mnemonic: Now we return to the more familiar form 高. Picture a tall sheet of rice (禾) paper (a long scroll?), on which a MANUSCRIPT is written. Note that this entry and the next one, following 高, have the on reading コウ, while the two characters above with 喬 are pronounced キョウ.

縞.mnemonic: Again let tall (高) suggest long—in this case, a thread (糸) running the length of a garment: pinSTRIPE.

箋.mnemonic: Imagine bamboo (⺮) tags used for labeling one's spears (戈): WRITING PAPER/label. The traditional form 箋 was retained when this kanji was added in 2010 to the official Joyo list; however, the spears portion had decades earlier been simplified to 戋 in the entries that follow. Learn to recognize both versions interchangeably.

残.mnemonic: To organize this set of five characters based on the simplified form 戋, let it represent some kind of vehicle transporting a stack of cargo. See it as facing to the right, and picture the diagonal stroke (S9 here) as a ramp used for unloading various objects. Here it LEAVES BEHIND a dead body (歹), RUTHLESSLY abandoning it to the elements.

桟.mnemonic: Here 戋 unloads a tree (木, i.e., a log), depositing it upright in order to support a SCAFFOLD. Note the traditional forms of this whole series of characters based on 戋.

銭.mnemonic: Here 戋 unloads money (金), in the form of a long trail of coins: MONEY/coin.

践.mnemonic: Here 戋 unloads a brave foot (足) soldier, who aims his rifle forward as he steps into battle: PUT INTO ACTION.

浅.mnemonic: Here a hose extends down the ramp, covering the street with a SHALLOW layer of water (氵).

洩.mnemonic: Visualize 曳 as a person dragging a hose, and water (氵) LEAKING from it.

壮.mnemonic: Review 将 0614 GENERAL OFFICER. In the present entry, we have wooden tablet (丬) and military man (士). Imagine a VIGOROUS military man GRANDLY and heroically carrying the wooden tablet entrusted to him by the general officer. Note the variant form of this and the next two entries.

荘.mnemonic: Grass (艹) + grand (壮): a stately country VILLA. Associate M2 DIGNIFIED with the same image.

装.mnemonic: Let “grand (壮) clothing (衣)” suggest the idea of adorning oneself in a special way, such as to create a particular appearance (DRESSING up/disguising oneself), or to prepare oneself for a certain purpose, such as battle (FITTING oneself OUT/equipping oneself).

冥.mnemonic: Sun (日) covered ( 冖 ) under six (六) layers: DARK. This character refers to darkness only in a metaphorical sense, and is used much less frequently than the next entry.

暗.mnemonic: Review 音 0150 and 闇 1364. It is relatively easy to remember that 闇 means DARK, given the enclosing quality of 門. Similarly, 日 here signals that the character refers not to sound but to the absence of light: DARK.

韻.mnemonic: This character's meaning is suggested by the RHYMING on-yomi of its component parts: 音 0150 オン/イン and 員 0317 イン. It is helpful to memorize the antonym pair V4 and V5.

損.mnemonic: Here a mistake committed by the hand (扌) of an employee (員) results in a LOSS.

捕.mnemonic: See 甫 as a fishing net: S4 here depicts the surface of a body of water, S9 a pole to hold the net underwater, 月 the netting, and S10 a fish leaping out of the water to avoid the net (distinguish 甫 from the (mixing) cauldron seen in 専 0580, 敷 1507, etc.). In the present entry, we see a hand (扌) using a fishing net to CATCH fish.

挿.mnemonic: If you look at the traditional form, it is easy to visualize a hand (扌) INSERTING the narrow stem of a flower into a vase. Now transfer that image to the simplified modern form.

補.mnemonic: Fishing nets (甫) must be regularly mended. Here we SUPPLEMENT/replenish the fishing net with cloth (ネ). Note that kanji with the phonetic component 甫 are read ホ.

浦.mnemonic: Picture a fishing net (甫) lying at the water (氵)'s edge: SEASIDE/small bay.

哺.mnemonic: Picture a nursing mother covering her breast with a fishing net (甫) and her baby opening its mouth (口) to SUCKLE.

舗.mnemonic: Here we observe a hut (舎) where fishing nets (甫) are sold. Lots of them. Only fishing nets and more fishing nets, covering everything, all over the SHOP. They even cover the hut's dirt floor, as a kind of reticulated PAVEMENT, and indeed PAVE the dirt side street that leads to the SHOP.

掴.mnemonic: Picture the hand (扌) GRASPING the kingdom (国).

捉.mnemonic: Recall the image of 足 as a person with “high heels” to emphasize his FEET/legs (see 0044). Here, visualize a hand (扌) trying to CATCH 足 by the heel. The mnemonic image notwithstanding, 捉 refers to apprehending ideas, not people; for the latter meaning, use 捕

促.mnemonic: Here visualize 亻 pushing 足 forward into action: HASTEN/urge. Note that both characters that incorporate 足 in the phonetic position follow its on reading, ソク.

筆.mnemonic: In 書 0079 WRITE, the tip of the writing brush (聿) was trimmed to accommodate the additional grapheme beneath it. Here (and in the entries that follow), it stretches right down to the tip. * suggests a bamboo BRUSH for WRITING.

津.mnemonic: Here picture 聿 as a ferry's rudder, writing a foamy wake across the water (氵) of the HARBOR, as if it were a writing brush.

律.mnemonic: 彳 suggests action, while 聿 suggests the written rules that regulate it: LAW. M2 RHYTHM is a kind of LAW governing the arrangement of sounds.

逮.mnemonic: 隶 combines three-fingered hand (⺕) with the five-stroke version of water (水). Visualize it as a hand spraying water from a hose. In this entry, imagine a squad of riot officers riding in on a truck (⻌) and subduing a gang of looters with water hoses: CATCH A CRIMINAL.

建.mnemonic: Let “writing brush (聿) + stretch (之)” suggest an architect's drawing up plans for an expan-

健.mnemonic: Man (亻) building (建) his body: ROBUST/healthy.

康.mnemonic: Here a hand sprays water from a hose (隶) on the plants in a shelter (广, i.e., a greenhouse). Associate the image with HEALTHY growth. On that note, let me remind you that to keep healthy and strong the kanji expertise you already have, you should by this stage be spend-ing a good part of your study time reading.

庸.mnemonic: Shelter (广) + writing brush (聿) + moon/month (月): picture a student who practices cal-ligraphy in his room only once a month, and therefore never makes much progress:

粛.mnemonic: Visualize a writer PURGING the ink from his writing brush (聿) by inserting it into a container of rice (米). The rice grains envelop the brush without making the slightest sound, and easily damp any vibrations it might make: HUSHED. One can hear the “HUSH” in the reading シュク.

繍.mnemonic: Here imagine that the three-fingered hand (ヨ) holds a needle rather than a brush, and picture it using the thread (糸) to stitch an eight-pointed rice design (米): EMBROIDERY.

唐.mnemonic: In this entry the writing brush (聿) is trimmed to accommodate 口 mouth. The latter symbolizes formal oratory, an art that developed in conjunction with that of writing. The two arts, shown under a sheltering (广) roof, symbolize the great cultural flowering of the TANG DYNASTY (China, 618-907 CE).

糖.mnemonic: The technology of sugar refinement arrived to East Asia during the Tang dynasty. The character for SUGAR thus combines those for rice (米, here suggesting a white granular substance) and Tang dynasty (唐).

粧.mnemonic: Note the difference between 圧 0186 and 庄 here. The latter is not a Joyo kanji, so we'll interpret it based on its parts, earth (土) and shelter (), and picture an earthenware jar inside a potter's workshop. Imagine applying a layer of rice (*) powder to beautify the jar: APPLY MAKEUP.

糧.mnemonic: Review 量 0538. Here, picture a cargo of rice (*) PROVISIONS being loaded onto the person's head. Compare the sample compounds with V3-5 of 料

粉.mnemonic: Picture 分 dividing (i.e., pulverizing) the rice at the left into rice flour: POWDER.

紛.mnemonic: Here thread (糸) suggests logical continuity or coherence. Picture 分 dividing the unified thread into various branches, creating CONFUSION.

糾.mnemonic: S7-9 is a form we first saw back at 収 1155, where we visualized it as a receptacle. Here, visualize it as an apparatus for twisting threads (糸) into rope. As we twist, we unify the threads into a coherent story line, like detectives reconstructing a “thread” of events. The image thus represents the act of INQUIRING INTO. In V1, it denotes twisting.

粋.mnemonic: suggests “nine (九) times ten (十),” or ninety. After writing 杂 a few times for practice, review 精 0976. Now whereas the term “quintessence” (or “fifth essence”) refers to a substance distilled through five stages of refinement, the present entry suggests a still higher degree of refinement: a grain of rice (米) REFINED to the ninetieth essence!

砕.mnemonic: CRUSH UP a stone (石) into ninety (午) pieces.

枠.mnemonic: The logs of ninety (午) trees (木), all put together: FRAME.

酔.mnemonic: Ninety (卆) bottles of liquor (酉): BECOME INTOXICATED.

醒.mnemonic: Review 星 if necessary. A star (星, i.e., the sun) shining on you, after liquor (酉): WAKE UP/sober up.

酬.mnemonic: Picture 酉 here as a bottle of liquor placed at one side of a sandbar-dotted river (州), an appealing reward for whoever can cross it: RECIPROCATE/recompense.

酷.mnemonic: Liquor (酉) + accuse (告): let this suggest cruel and SEVERE accusations spoken by a drunk person.

凡.mnemonic: Recall table/tablecloth. Here it appears by itself as a tablecloth with a single decorative mark on it (S3). As an object that is spread over a wide area (i.e., “widespread”), it came to denote the idea COMMONPLACE/mediocre. In 帆 1631 and 汎 1632, it will signify spread widely.

凧.mnemonic: A cloth (巾) KITE flying in the wind (八). To review the distinction between 凡and ㄦ, see

帆.mnemonic: A cloth (巾) spread widely (凡) to catch the wind: SAIL.

汎.mnemonic: Spread widely (凡) across the surface of the water (氵), so as to reach and encompass every-one: PAN- (as in “Pan-Pacific”)

恐.mnemonic: When it appears next to 工 (the I beam, representing construction), let 凡 suggest a carpenter's table. The thought of I beams, table saws, and other dangerous objects arouses FEAR in one's heart (心).

怖.mnemonic: Imagine unfolding this cloth (布) and discovering a beating, bloody heart (忄) organ wrapped inside: FEARFUL!

築.mnemonic: Bamboo (⺮) + scaffolding + I beam (工) + carpenter's table (凡, see 1633) + lumber (木): finding all these together, we know we must be looking at a CONSTRUCTION site.

尋.mnemonic: Let hand (ヨ) and outstretched arm (寸) together signify a detective's looking for something with both hands. 口 mouth suggests the detective's oral questioning, and 工 his professional workmanship. Taken as a whole, the ensemble suggests a formal INQUIRY.

訊.mnemonic: On the right, picture a person standing in a doorway asking questions. See how he steps forward to try to catch his respondent's every word (言): INTERROGATE/ask. Now usually replaced by the previous entry.

諮.mnemonic: A distinctive feature of this kanji is the pair of strokes (7) sandwiched in the middle. Use that 欠 as a visual shortcut to the idea of CONSULTING/asking for advice: see 欠 as a person asking for advice, and as information passing from the words of advice (言) into the advice-seeker's ear (S10).

抗.mnemonic: shows a flat tabletop with 一 over it to emphasize the idea of straightness. With 扌, it suggests an arm held straight out in RESISTANCE. Visualize S5 as a resisting stiff arm. Note that all three kanji incorporating 亢 are pronounced コウ.

航.mnemonic: Making sure a boat (舟) travels in a straight (元) line: NAVIGATION.

坑.mnemonic: A straight (亢) shaft dug into the earth (土): PIT (of a mine).

拝.mnemonic: The image at the right suggests the interlocking fingers of hands joined in prayer: WORSHIP.

耕.mnemonic: In this entry, 井 will not represent well (see 0434), but instead furrows in a farm field. 耒 is a new grapheme meaning plow, which we can visualize here as a three-bladed rotary tiller rolling across those furrows, TILLING the soil in a crisscross pattern. The diagonal lines at the lower left (S5-6) show the TILLED soil being tossed to one side.

耗.mnemonic: (Continuing from the previous entry) Now the rotary tiller (未) is used to grind up wool (毛). Picture how quickly the wool WEARS AWAY under the harrowing contact of the rotary tiller. This image is captured well in the sample compound 摩耗する(まもうする, wear away, wear out; see 摩 2099).

崇.mnemonic: In Japan, temples have often been built at the base of hills or mountains, the place where man may approach the infinite. Reflecting this practice, this character places a house of worship (宗) at the foot of a mountain (山) to represent the idea of human REVERENCE toward the elevated and the sacred.

灰.mnemonic: Picture a fire (火) producing a great mound of ASH, as tall as a cliff (厂).

炭.mnemonic: Here a mountain (山) buries ash (灰), compressing it so heavily it turns to COAL. Associate the compression of the ash here (compared to the previous entry) with the greater density of COAL vis-à-vis ash.

岸.mnemonic: Here we observe a high mountain (山) cliff (厂), with the grapheme 干 to signify dry. Seeing the latter, we recognize that this kanji refers to the SHORE, in the same sense in which sea-weary sailors might use the expression "dry land" in English.

岩.mnemonic: Recall that 石 stone uses a variation on. Visualize the present entry as a stone protruding from the side of a mountain (山): ROCK/crag.

崩.mnemonic: See 朋 not as two moons but as two massive piles of earth pouring down from a mountain (山) in a landslide. Two valleys separate the mountain's three peaks; see one pile of earth CRUMBLING down from each valley. A useful on-yomi compound to memorize appears at 壊

嵐.mnemonic: Behold the winds (風) of a STORM blowing down from a mountain (山).

崖.mnemonic: To compose the kanji for CLIFF, we visually reinforce cliff (厂) with mountain (山) and piled layers of earth (圭).

催.mnemonic: The man (亻) at the left has SPONSORED a bird (隹) reserve in the mountains (山). To capture the broad sense of this character, think of the efforts he has made to PRESS FOR the reserve's creation and finally make it happen.

焦.mnemonic: Imagine how desperately IMPATIENT the bird (佳) must be as it sits on a fire (灬), being SCORCHED.

礁.mnemonic: Observe the bird (佳) alighting on the scorching-hot rocks (石) of an exposed REEF.

奮.mnemonic: Visualize the bird (佳)'s first sitting passively in a rice field (田), then suddenly being ROUSED UP, spreading its wings "big" (大), and briskly flying away. Use 大 more as a visual clue than a semantic one: see S2-3 as the bird's wings flapping vigorously as it attempts to ROUSE itself UP.

奪.mnemonic: (Building on the previous entry) Now we see what the bird (佳) is getting all roused up about: a predator is reaching up with an outstretched arm (寸) to SEIZE it before it can fly away.

隻.keywords: ONE OF A PAIR, COUNTER FOR SHIPS
隻.mnemonic: The traditional form of 双 1498 SET OF TWO was 雙, showing a hand holding a pair of birds. The present entry is used in contrast to that, showing a hand holding only one of the birds, to signify the idea ONE OF A PAIR. It has not been simplified to 又 because such a character already exists (0058).

獲.mnemonic: The next three characters include 隻. Picture it as an adult bird (佳) grasping some grass (++++) within its talons (suggested by 又 hand). In the present entry, then, we have grasp + smallish four-legged creature (歹): CATCH GAME.

穫.mnemonic: (Continuing from the previous entry) Grasp (隻) + rice (禾): HARVEST.

護.mnemonic: ing fierce words (言) to PROTECT its possession.

譲.mnemonic: at the right is based on the split version of garment(衣). Picture it as a garment whose interior has been padded with fluffy lining (S10-16). With 言 it refers to the words of a compromise-negotiating mediator who inserts soft “padding” between two disputing parties. From this idea the character has come to mean CEDE/yield.

嬢.mnemonic: 女 woman + 襄 pad with fluffy lining = a padded, fluffy way of addressing a YOUNG LADY. Note that 襄 in this series of characters is a simplification of 襄, which shows the “padding” even more clearly. Take some time to practice writing the simplified version, remembering to start and finish with 衣.

醸.mnemonic: 西 liquor jar + 襄 pad with fluffy lining refers to the addition of fermenting agents into a cask: BREW. Note that all these kanji incorporating 襄 are pronounced ジョウ、

壌.mnemonic: “土 earth+襄 padded and fluffy”: ARABLE SOIL.

壊.mnemonic: Take S4-10 in the upper right as a variant of 直 straight/upright. Combined with 衣 garment, it suggests a straight-cut gown. In this entry, imagine that a person's straight-cut gown gets caught on the ground (土) and tears apart: BREAK DOWN. Note that the right side is a simplification of 裏.

懐.mnemonic: This character refers to the heart (忄) hidden beneath one's (straight-cut) gown: BOSOM. Behind the gown, we hide our tears (visible in the traditional form), and shroud our private loves and LONGINGS.

徳.mnemonic: Again, take the upper right as a variant of 直 straight/upright. Together with 心, it suggests upright heart, which here combines with 彳 action to signify virtuous action, or simply VIRTUE.

聴.mnemonic: Ear (耳) + upright heart: together these suggest attentive LISTENING.

恥.mnemonic: Ear (耳) + heart (心): suggests a feeling brought on by the consciousness of others' opinions of us: SHAME. Picture a word of reproach passing through the ear and causing great distress to the heart.

羞.mnemonic: The ox (丑) feels ASHAMED for associating with the goat (羊). See how he hides under-neath the goat out of SHAME.

爵.mnemonic: Visualize 罒 as kind of crown, which 爫 (claw) places on the heads of the two small graphemes appearing at the bottom. Imagine that these two are minor gentry, and that the claw bestows upon them the RANK OF NOBILITY.

侯.mnemonic: Picture the right half of this character as the granting of an arrow (矢), i.e., the Crown's bestowal of a feudal title in exchange for military service. With 亻 for man, it signifies FEUDAL LORD.

喉.mnemonic: (Continuing from the previous entry) This time imagine the king shoving the arrow through the feudal lord (侯)'s mouth (□) and down his THROAT.

候.mnemonic: Picture a feudal lord (侯) using a rod (S3) to divine the weather for this season: SEASONAL WEATHER; SEASON. Note that both characters incorporating 侯 follow its on reading, コウ.

修.mnemonic: Review the note at 参 1238. Here a man (亻) strikes (攵) himself with a rod (S3) to discipline himself in his efforts at self-improvement. As you write out 彡, imagine that these three lines represent progressive stages of his training, self-improving, or repairing, thus signifying M1 CULTIVATE (oneself)/study and M2 REPAIR.

悠.mnemonic: Meaning LEISURELY/serene, this character can be seen as a kind of reversal of the previous one. Let heart (心) signify compassion toward the disciplined self-improver, mercifully replacing the staged training process (represented by 彡 in the previous entry) with a moment of LEISURE.

是.mnemonic: Suggests the sun (日)'s straight (正) path through the sky: RIGHT/correct. Both RIGHT and correct derive from the Latin word rectus, meaning "straight," which is what we shall call 是 when it appears inside other kanji. These follow presently.

提.mnemonic: One should hold one's hand (扌) straight (是) out when PRESENTING a gift, business card, etc.

堤.mnemonic: Straightened (是) earth (土): EMBANKMENT. The next entry, by the way, will be one of the last high-frequency kanji you will learn. Once you've learned it, it would be prudent to reduce the time you spend acquiring new kanji, in favor of more reading. You now have more to lose by forgetting kanji you've already learned than to gain by learning new ones.

題.mnemonic: Review 是 1678. Let “head (頁) straight (是)” suggest the straight, rectangular, flat part of the head: the forehead. As the most visible and topmost part of the body, the forehead symbolizes HEADING or headline. HEADING is closely related to M2 TOPIC, which we can easily associate with M3 PROBLEM/question.

匙.mnemonic: We have already seen the spoon grapheme (匕) inside many kanji. Here we meet the kanji for SPOON itself, composed of spoon and straight (是), in reference to a spoon's straight handle.

冒.mnemonic: A naked eye (目), staring bravely at the sun (日): RISK/defy.

昌.mnemonic: Think of how CLEAR and bright the world would be if we had two suns (日). V1 is related to the idea of a bright outlook.

唱.mnemonic: The mouth 口 singing clearly 昌 sounds like intone.

帽.mnemonic: Unlike in 冒1683, here a piece of cloth (巾) is used to protect the eye (目) from the sun (日)'s rays: HEADGEAR. The on-yomi follows 冒.

棟.mnemonic: Review 陳 1373. In this entry 木 tree + 東 all the way through/across refers to a ridgepole, the beam that runs across the top of a sloping roof, anchoring the rafters on either side. As the ridgepole passes through the whole length of the building, 棟 is most often used in reference to entire BUILDINGS.

凍.mnemonic: Ice (7) + all the way through (東): thoroughly FROZEN.

氷.mnemonic: The only difference between the characters for ICE (in this entry) and WATER (水 0027) is S2, which we should therefore visualize as an icicle.

永.mnemonic: To distinguish this character from 氷 1690 ICE and 水 0027 WATER, focus on S1-2. These form a dotted letter “i,” as in “infinity”: ETERNAL/long.

泳.mnemonic: Let “long(永) water(氵)” suggest a long and narrow pool for SWIMMING. Note that the two characters incorporating 永 follow its on reading, エイ.

詠.mnemonic: Words (言) that put us in touch with the infinite (水): POETRY.

札.mnemonic: Picture carving some words onto a piece of wood with a sharp hook (L): TAG/label.

枚.mnemonic: Let this suggest striking (父) or pounding wood (木) until it is FLAT. This character is used for counting thin, FLAT THINGS, such as sheets of paper.

杯.mnemonic: 木 suggests wooden material. Let 不 graphically represent a long-stemmed glass. Since Japanese uses the word コップ for wineglass, it won't hurt us that our keyword for 杯 is not glass but CUP.

析.mnemonic: Picture using the hacksaw (斤) to take the tree (木) apart, breaking it down into its constituent elements: ANALYZE.

折.mnemonic: Notice how the frame of the hacksaw (斤) is bent (at S5). This, we can imagine, was achieved by the hand (扌) at the left, pulling with all its might. Now imagine that it continues bending the frame until it either FOLDS or BREAKS OFF.

挫.mnemonic: Visualize the hand (扌) getting BROKEN or sprained on this pointy object (坐). The on-yomi follows 坐 and 座.

捻.mnemonic: Let “hand (扌) + thought (念)” suggest turning something around and around in one's mind, as if with one's hand. It refers to the physical act of TWISTING, or the mental act of contriving a solution at some effort.

誓.mnemonic: To SWEAR or vow is to declare that one's word will not be broken. This idea is graphically represented here by S9, which draws an impregnable line over one's word (言), protecting it from any possibility that 折 could break it.

逝.mnemonic: Advance (辶) + broken (折): think of this as an old, broken body moving on from this world, i.e., DEPARTING THIS LIFE.

哲.mnemonic: Mouth (口) + break (折): think of the mouth as that of a WISE PHILOSOPHER, speaking incisive logic.

斬.mnemonic: Hacksaw (斤) cutting car (車) in two: KILL/cut down. The kun reading きる (斬る) can be associated, via the idea of cutting down, with 切る (きる, cut). Alternatively, it can be associated with the English "KILL."

漸.mnemonic: After the car is cut (斬), drops of motor oil (Y) GRADUALLY drain out.

暫.mnemonic: Cutting (斬) out a little slice of the day-just a SHORT WHILE.

斥.mnemonic: With S5, this hacksaw (斤)'s manufacturer has marked it as defective, and consigned it to scrap. It has been REJECTED.

訴.mnemonic: Words (言) spoken in rejection (斥): SUE/complain. Also means APPEAL TO, from the idea of seeking attention for some adverse condition.

訟.mnemonic: “Words (言) + public (公)” suggests taking one's claim to a public tribunal: LITIGATE.

究.mnemonic: Nine (九), the last digit in the decimal system, here suggests “reaching the end,” as in exploring a cave (穴) to its furthest depths. The full character thus implies getting to the bottom of an unfamiliar subject: STUDY EXHAUSTIVELY.

窮.mnemonic: Here we observe a body (身) contorted into the shape of a bow (弓) so as to squeeze itself inside a small hole (穴): PUSHED TO THE LIMIT.

極.mnemonic: As a shortcut, see the two horizontal strokes S5 and S12 as POLAR EXTREMES. It takes the full length of the tree (木) to reach from one end to the other, emphasizing the great distance between them.

函.mnemonic: Looks like a BOX, filled with foam packing peanuts (S3-6), that has just been opened.

探.mnemonic: Treat ク as a variant on 穴 hole. Now when you see this character, imagine PROBING around a hole in a tree (木) with your hand (扌).

深.mnemonic: (Continuing from the previous entry) Now imagine that, DEEP at the bottom of the hole (ク口) in the tree (木), you feel rainwater (氵).

慄.mnemonic: Think of the bones in your spine as a string of chestnuts. With ↑, chestnuts thus suggest an emotion you feel in your spine: shuddering/TREMBLING.

惧.mnemonic: The right-hand portion of this entry is the old form of 具. While the independent kanji 具 was modified as part of the orthographic reforms that followed World War II, the present entry was not so modified when it was added to the Joyo list in 2010. In the same way as 恐 1633, it suggests a FEAR of dangerous tools.

慎.mnemonic: Keeping the truth (真) in one's heart (忄): PRUDENT/discreet.

鎮.mnemonic: Pacifying someone with true (真) gold (金): QUELL/appease.

塡.mnemonic: 眞 is the old form of 真. This portion was not officially standardized with 真 when the present entry was added to the Joyo list in 2010, but the standardized form (填) is also used. Learn to recognize both forms interchangeably. The meaning comes from the idea of FILLING IN soil to make the ground (土) "true," i.e., level.

婚.mnemonic: Woman (女) + family (氏, review 0476 if needed) + (wedding) day (日): MARRY.

困.mnemonic: Tree (木) trapped inside enclosure (□), its growth stunted: IN TROUBLE.

梱.mnemonic: PACKAGE/bale: depicts a tree (木) before and after being PACKAGED inside a box.

因.mnemonic: To connect this image with the idea of CAUSATION, let the enclosure (□) suggest CAUSAL circumstances, and let 大 suggest the “big” (i.e., main) CAUSE.

姻.mnemonic: Suggests that MARRIAGE is something a woman (女) might cause (因). However, if you don’t mind conflating 因 with 囚, the image easily suggests a woman holding a (big) man prisoner. VI is the more common of the two sample compounds, but the easy association between 姻族 (いんぞく) and “in-laws” makes V2 mnemonically useful.

咽.mnemonic: Except where 因 appears at the top (in the next entry), all kanji in this course containing 因 are pronounced イン. Knowing that, you should be able to recognize mouth (口) + 因 as the イン of 咽喉 (いんこう, throat). Concern yourself only with learning that compound, and the associative pathway to it from the semantic and phonetic clues of 咽.

恩.mnemonic: The English words GRACE and GRATITUDE refer to either side of the cause-effect relationship that exists when a favor is given: GRACE is the cause (因), and GRATITUDE is the result. See both sides of this relationship in 恩: 因 represents the (cause of) GRACE; 心 represents the (resulting) DEBT OF GRATITUDE.

菌.mnemonic: Let ✢ suggest a fungus or other microorganism growing on a box (□) of rice (禾): BACTERIA/germ/fungus.

漢.mnemonic: Review 難 0712. Here we see the Han scholar-official next to water (氵). The Han dynasty's power largely rested on its effective control of water, so it is fitting that this character is used in reference to the dynasty itself (it also refers more generally to the ancient CHINESE). Associate M2 FELLOW with the image of the official.

嘆.mnemonic: Here imagine the mouth (口) of the Han scholar-official letting out a SIGH of lament, perhaps over the sovereign's failure to live up to the Confucian ideal of moral leadership and just rule. Like the other kanji using the scholar-official with his legs spread apart (難 0712 and 漢 1730), the on-yomi ends in -AN.

勤.mnemonic: The following three kanji show the Han scholar-official with his legs joined together. Kanji using this version are pronounced キン. Here we observe the scholar-official busy at work behind a plow (力), illustrating the ideas SERVICE, work, and employment.

謹.mnemonic: Picture the Han scholar-official addressing the sovereign with RESPECTFUL, carefully chosen words (言). Note the traditional form for this entry and the one before: this old form of the scholar-official is retained in the next entry.

僅.mnemonic: Only A FEW men (亻) were selected as Han scholar-officials. Note how the scholar-official differs slightly here from the previous two entries. 僅 was not officially standardized to match them when it was added to the Joyo list, but its standardized form (shown in the variant field) is also accepted.

索.mnemonic: Visualize S1-4 as a person standing at the top of a long shaft, and 糸 as a rope that he's using to SEARCH FOR something in the shaft. Now imagine his raising the rope to look at what he's retrieved, in the same way one goes through the results obtained by an internet SEARCH (see V4).

牽.mnemonic: A distinctive and easily recognizable feature of this character is that passes through the middle of it. It is therefore a good idea to focus on this feature and associate it with the character's meaning, PULL. Picture as a handle by which a child (幺) PULLS along a cow (牛).

牢.mnemonic: Picture a cow (牛) under the HARD stone roof (宀) of the PRISON (the “hoosecow,” if you will).

啓.mnemonic: Visualize as a face with its mouth (口) and right eye (戸) opening wide in response to a striking (攵) insight: ENLIGHTENMENT. As a form of RESPECTFUL ADDRESS, it expresses admiration for the enlightening wisdom of the person one is addressing.

庶.mnemonic: From 席 and 度, recall the image of 廿 as the open mouth of a woodburning stove. Here, focus on the MANIFOLD flames beneath the stove.

遮.mnemonic: Picture manifold (庶) objects piled on the truck (辶), which drives in front of you from the right side, blocking your advance: INTERRUPT/cut off. The reading さえぎる (遮る, interrupt, obstruct, cut off) sounds a bit like “side-きる,” or “cut (off)” from the side.

燕.mnemonic: A top-down view into a SWALLOW's nest. In the center rests a tiny SWALLOW's egg (□).

抄.mnemonic: Hand (扌) picking out just a little (少): EXCERPT/select.

秒.mnemonic: Imagine an hourglass with tiny grains of rice, in lieu of sand. Each little (少) grain of rice (禾) marks one SECOND of time.

妙.mnemonic: Little (少) woman (女): suggests the MARVELOUS, strangely enchanting beauty of a dainty female figure.

沙.mnemonic: Little (少) stones next to water(氵): SAND. The usual character for SAND is 砂 0678;沙 is generally limited to V1-2 of the next entry.

汰.mnemonic: Suggests using water (氵) to SIFT OUT a relatively “thick” (太) item. For example, imagine washing gravel in a pan to SIFT OUT gold or silver. A similar mnemonic works well for the unlisted 淘 (トウ, SELECT) in V3-4, showing an elephant (勹) prospector “selecting” out gold or silver by washing gravel in a can (缶).

煎.mnemonic: BOILING/roasting on a fire (灬) before (前) eating. This character was not officially standardized with 煎 when it was added to the Joyo list, but you'll also see it in standardized form.

炊.mnemonic: Gaping mouth (欠) blowing fire (火) on food: COOK.

焚.mnemonic: Forest (林) over fire (火): KINDLE/build a fire.

薪.mnemonic: Review 新 0275. Here the standing person cuts new (新) branches for FIREWOOD. + grass suggests slender sprigs, just right for kindling.

乃.mnemonic: This kanji appears as the POSSESSIVE PARTICLE の in archaic or archaic-style texts in which kana are not used (note its similarities with the hiragana の and katakana ノ, both of which were derived from this kanji). Other possible uses appear in V2 and V3. Note how S2 changes directions four times.

之.mnemonic: Like the previous entry, this character appears in archaic texts as the POSSESSIVE PARTICLE の. V2 provides another possible usage. Do not confuse with the hiragana え.

此.mnemonic: Visualize 止 as two men standing behind a third man (匕), who points toward something. To refer to the object to which he has drawn their attention, he says “THIS…” Inside other kanji, 此 can provide an image of three men looking at something that has drawn their attention.

其.mnemonic: We learned this form back at 基 0485, where we gave it the meaning bind/bound. As an independent kanji, it means THAT, as in 其の人(そのひと, that person). Like the preceding three entries, you won't frequently come across 其 as an independent kanji.

乏.mnemonic: S1-2 resemble the mortarboard and tassel of the student's formal gown, which you might associate with a student's impoverished lifestyle: SCANTY/poor.

芝.mnemonic: When you see 之 with 艹 grass, you might visualize it as a hand-pushed lawn mower: LAWN GRASS.

及.keywords: REACH TO, extend to; be equal to; as well as, and
及.mnemonic: Note the ways in which this form differs from 乃 above. To perceive the idea REACH TO, focus visually on how S2 REACHES over TO the left, and S3 REACHES over TO the right. The way they both extend to the other side recalls 廴 stretch (introduced back at 延 0872). In the three entries that follow, 及 will signify reach.

扱.mnemonic: Following the previous entry, see how S5 and S6 reach. Now visualize the whole kanji as a hand(扌) reaching out to HANDLE/treat something.

級.mnemonic: Suggests military insignia, that is, thread (糸) that shows one has reached (及) a certain GRADE or rank. While the previous entry does not have an on reading, this one and the one after follow the on reading of 及, キュウ、

吸.mnemonic: Picture the mouth (口) reaching (及) out to SUCK in/BREATHE IN air. Note how two of the three strokes in 及 seem to get SUCKED toward 口. The reading すう resembles the sound your mouth makes when you SUCK in air, as when you're sipping hot “soooooup” (see V5).

吹.mnemonic: Mouth (口) + gaping mouth (欠): breathe out/BLOW. To distinguish from the previous entry, note how S5 seems to point away from the mouth, whereas in the previous entry, two of the three strokes in 及 get sucked toward it. On-yomi compounds appear at 鼓 2016 and 奏2104.

呼.mnemonic: Visualize the mouth (□) CALLING to 乎 and getting its attention. Note how, in contrast to 平 0334, 乎 has two strokes that either lean (S4, in the head character) or hook (S8) toward the mouth, graphically representing how the mouth has attracted its attention.

叶.mnemonic: If you visualize + as pointing down from the mouth (□), it suggests a word coming down from the mouth of a higher-up, FULFILLING/granting a subordinate's request.

叱.mnemonic: Visualize □ as the mouth of an adult, SCOLDING a seated child (匕).

叫.mnemonic: Visualize 丩 as a hand held up to one's mouth (□) to amplify the volume of one's voice while SHOUTING. S5 represents the thumb, held out to fit under the chin. S4 and the top of S6 represent the fingers, while the bottom of S6 represents the wrist.

吟.mnemonic: When it appears next to now (今), let mouth (口) suggest singing or RECITING in precise time.

含.mnemonic: A good way to distinguish this from the previous entry is to see the larger □ here as a box rather than a mouth. This entry thus refers to what is presently(今) inside a box, to signify the idea CONTAIN/include. Remember, the smaller □ in the previous entry represents a mouth, while the larger □ in this entry represents a box.

琴.mnemonic: Following 吟 above, 今 suggests playing in precise (musical) time. The top of the character depicts the strings of the KOTO.

迷.mnemonic: See the eight lines of the rice (米) grapheme all pointing in different directions. 辶 indicates that we're trying to go somewhere, but 米 indicates that we don't know which way to go. We're lost/PERPLEXED.
