謎.mnemonic: Words (言) that perplex(迷): RIDDLE/enigma. Like other new Joyo kanji that contain, this entry was not officially simplified to 辶 when it was added to the Joyo Kanji List. Remember, it is always acceptable to write 辶 in place of .

逆.mnemonic: Imagine that S6 started out vertical. Then the truck (3) suddenly sped forward, sending the object loaded on it tumbling backward. 逆 depicts that instant, when the two objects move in REVERSE directions.

遡.keywords: GO BACK IN TIME, go upstream
遡.mnemonic: To 逆 reverse we now add 月 month, to suggest the idea of going in reverse through time: GOING BACK IN TIME.

塑.mnemonic: Use the curving shape of S6 and S7 as a visual cue for the idea of giving shape to an object. See both parts of 朔 working together as a MODEL to mold a malleable chunk of earth (土).

勲.mnemonic: Moving (動) directly over searing flames (m): MERITORIOUS SERVICE.

薫.mnemonic: Herbs (+) piled (重) atop a fire (灬), burning fragrantly: BALMY/fragrant.

芳.mnemonic: Picture a person (方) running through a FRAGRANT meadow filled with herbs (+).

香.mnemonic: Bundled rice (禾), mellowing in the sunshine (日): SWEET SMELL.

秀.mnemonic: When乃 appears inside other kanji, see it as a hand or rod (ノ) pulling an object ( ㄋ) away toward the left. Here, we thus have a rice bundle (禾) being pulled away from "the chaff," to signify EXCELLENCE. Now review the differences between 乃 and 及. The reading ひいでる (excel, stand out) sounds like 引いて (ひいて, pulling) + 出る (でる, go out).

誘.mnemonic: This character includes the previous entry in full, but we should still focus visually on 乃 and how its left-hand stroke seems to pull away. Words (言) attempting to pull (someone) away: INDUCE/invite.

拐.mnemonic: Do you notice anything odd about this character? By now, you are probably used to seeing knife (刀) over mouth (口) in kanji based on 召, but here, the knife and mouth are reversed. In this way, think of this entry as the conceptual opposite of politely INVITING (招): KIDNAPPING.

透.mnemonic: Here again focus visually on 乃 and how its left-hand stroke seems to pull toward the left. With 之 advance, we should think of pulling or advancing through a barrier: PASS THROUGH. Also means SEE-THROUGH/transparent, from the idea of light PASSING THROUGH a barrier.

携.mnemonic: Hand (扌) + bird (隹) + pull away (乃): here visualize the hand carrying the bird away (like a portable phone): CARRY IN HAND.

雄.mnemonic: Think of 広 as a hand (ナ) placed on a nose (ム). Then visualize this character as a MALE bravely and HEROICALLY placing his hand upon a bird (隹)'s nose (i.e., beak).

雌.mnemonic: Recall from 此 1756 the image of three men looking at something that has drawn their attention. Here they are three male birds, gawking at a lovely FEMALE bird (隹).

些.mnemonic: Because the top stroke of is narrower than the lower stroke, we can visualize it here as a pyramid shape, narrowing at the top. Notice how there's only A LITTLE BIT of space at the top of S7 for the three men (此) to fit.

柴.mnemonic: Here visualize 此 as slender branches at the top of a tree (木): BRUSHWOOD/firewood.

紫.mnemonic: Here the three men (此)'s attention has been drawn by a flamboyant PURPLE thread(糸).

髪.mnemonic: 髟 means hair. Picture彡 as a comb, and S2-4 as long locks of hair. With 友 friend, this entry depicts a person having her HAIR combed by a friend.

髭.mnemonic: Distinguish from the previous entry by using 匕 (similar to katakana ヒ) as a quick clue for ひげ (BEARD/mustache).

詐.mnemonic: Review 0153-54. Here, we fabricate words (言) as with a saw (乍): SWINDLE. A useful compound to memorize appears in the next entry. Remember to associate the English word "saw" with the on readings サ and サク, one or both of which apply to all kanji in this course containing 乍,

欺.mnemonic: Imagine a scenario in which a person has been duped into letting in a robber, who ties him up and then makes off with his valuables. In this kanji we see the person bound up (其), his mouth gaping (欠) in shock at how he's been DECEIVED.

棋.mnemonic: In the next two entries, let 其 represent a rectangular grid, on which one plays a game of chess or checkers. The game with the wooden (木) pieces is SHOGI (Japanese chess). (Continued in next entry)

碁.mnemonic: (Continuing from the previous entry) The game with the stone (石) pieces is GO (Japanese checkers).

甚.mnemonic: Returning to the meaning bind/bound for 其, we can visualize in this entry a person bound to “the stocks,” an EXTREME form of punishment. S6 represents the boards locked around the detainee's legs, which can be seen dangling below (儿). Associate the image not with punishment, but with the idea of EXTREMENESS.

勘.mnemonic: Here we observe the detainee (甚) CHECKING out the plow (力) left next to him, consider- ing it for potential use in an escape plot. To the extent that he naturally understands how to make use of the plow, the character can also represent the idea of INTUITIVE PERCEPTION.

堪.mnemonic: Finally, picture the detainee (甚) suffering the additional humiliation of being pelted by clods of dirt (土), hurled at him by scornful passers-by: ENDURE.

匹.mnemonic: We first encountered back at 区. Here, it represents an animal cage with an opening at the side. Inside it we find human legs (儿), which we should interpret, by way of exception, to be animal legs: COUNTER FOR ANIMALS. Distinguish from 四 FOUR by the lack of the "fourth" side,四

匠.mnemonic: Now picture as a storage box with an opening on one side. A hacksaw (斤) stored inside this box symbolizes the CRAFTSMAN.

匿.mnemonic: In this entry, the box (匚) is used not to store, but to CONCEAL. Picture it CONCEALING a young person (若) from the public gaze.

諾.mnemonic: Picture the young person (若) holding words (言), the way a young schoolchild holds words of parental CONSENT on a permission slip as he reports to school on the day of a field trip.

乞.mnemonic: Visualize 乙 as a BEGGAR kneeling and holding out his hands, and as a charitable person standing above him, holding out an arm (S2) to give him a handout.

迄.mnemonic: Beggar (乞) hitching a ride on a truck (_), as far as it will take him: UP TO/until. Note that まで is usually written in hiragana.

乾.mnemonic: Alcoholic beggar (乞) “DRYING” out in the morning (from 朝 0145).

幹.mnemonic: Here interpret 干 visually, as a tree TRUNK with two sets of branches (see ^ as the tree's canopy). From 朝 0145, recall that the left side of this character depicts the sun (日) rising through two cross-shaped plants. Let that image suggest “rising straight up,” just as a tree TRUNK does.

操.mnemonic: Think of 杲 as a tree (木) with fruit (品), which the hand (扌) carefully and dexterously picks:

燥.mnemonic: Now we use fire (火) to DRY OUT the fruit (品, following previous entry).

繰.mnemonic: Here, picture 品 as cotton bolls, whose thread (糸) is being spun onto REELS. M2 SHIFT ONWARD comes from the idea of shifting thread from a cotton boll or silk cocoon onto a REEL. Note that while this entry has no on-yomi, the others incorporating 果 are all pronounced ソウ.

藻.mnemonic: This time, the focus shifts to 艹 and 氵, which suggest that 杲 is in this case a grass-like plant growing in water. SEAWEED.

噴.mnemonic: 賁 depicts a shellfish swollen to bursting. With 口 to suggest the mouth of a geyser or volcano, it signifies SPOUT/gush out. The three kanji that incorporate 賁 are all pronounced フン。

墳.mnemonic: Earth (土) + swollen to bursting (賁): TUMULUS.

憤.mnemonic: Heart (忄) + swollen to bursting (賁): INDIGNATION.

牙.mnemonic: Depicts a FANG or tusk. Note the slight difference between the independent kanji and the grapheme version, seen in the next entry.

雅.mnemonic: Bird (隹) with an ELEGANT, slender, fang (牙)-like beak, like a hummingbird's.

邪.mnemonic: Here we observe a fanged(牙) beast that has surmounted the town walls and is now inside the town (邑). Let this image symbolize EVIL.

既.mnemonic: At the right, notice how 无 differs from牙 of the previous few entries. We shall still see it as a fang. Focus on how the fang has ALREADY wrapped all the way around the little boy (旦)—he's ALREADY done for. Note the variant forms for this and the next two entries.

概.mnemonic: The little boy (B) is larger than the usual prey, so the fanged (无) beast will have to measure him first to be sure it can actually swallow him. Here we observe the fanged beast using a piece of wood (木) to make a GENERAL/rough measure of the size of his quarry.

慨.mnemonic: Here a heart (忄) DEPLORES what is happening to the little boy (B) in 既 1820. Remembering this idea, practice writing this character in alternation with 既 and 概, focusing on distinguishing their meanings.

苗.mnemonic: Young plant (++) sprouting in a recently seeded rice field (田): SEEDLING.

描.mnemonic: Hand (扌) using a seedling (苗) as a brush, to DEPICT things.

猫.mnemonic: A smallish four-legged creature (3), gentle and lithe enough to walk among the seedlings (苗): CAT. As a visual shortcut, you might associate 艹 with a CAT's whiskers.

萌.mnemonic: Rather than use bright from 明, I suggest you visualize grass (++) sprouting atop the sun (日): GERMINATE.

兆.keywords: SIGN, omen; show signs of, TRILLION
兆.mnemonic: 萌す(きざす, previous entry, V4) and 兆す(きざす, V3 here) overlap in signifying "sprout" and "show signs of," so see 兆 as a pair of stalks with buds showing signs of blossoming. M2 TRILLION should be practiced together with 万 0018 TEN THOUSAND and 億 0622 HUNDRED MILLION.

眺.mnemonic: What is an eye (目) to do when placed next to a pair of stalks with flowers that are about to break out of their knobby buds (兆), other than GAZE at them, as long as it takes, until they finally blossom? The reading ながめる (眺める, gaze) sounds like 長い(ながい, long) + 見る(みる, see, view).

逃.mnemonic: Picture a dishonest plant lover pulling the budding stalks (兆) up from their roots and spirit-ing them away on the back of a truck (辶) to his private flower garden: ESCAPE.

桃.mnemonic: 木 suggests tree species. What we must memorize, then, is that the tree's budding flowers (兆) are those of the PEACH. Picture the buds first flowering to attract pollinators, then ripening into big, velvety, juicy, thirst-slaking PEACHES.

跳.mnemonic: See 足 as a person getting ready to spring his legs and JUMP right over the two budding stalks (兆).

挑.mnemonic: See the two short crossing strokes of 扌 hand (its fingers) PROVOKING the budding stalks (兆): they are picking at the top-left bud, and in an instant they will have plucked it off. Focus for a moment on the place where the fingers are about to pinch off the helpless bud, and sense the prospect of imminent violence. Now test yourself on this 兆 set.

拙.mnemonic: Here we observe a hand (才) slipping out (出) of place, which signifies the idea of CLUMSINESS.

屈.mnemonic: Now we shall make use of 尸's additional sense buttocks, which we learned back at 尾 0488. The present entry refers to "putting out(出) one's buttocks," i.e., the act of BENDING over.

掘.mnemonic: Bend over (屈) and DIG with your hands (扌). Note that while the next entry has no on-yomi, the other three with 屈, including the present entry, are all pronounced クツ.

堀.mnemonic: Once used interchangeably with the previous entry, but now used only for the noun ほり (DITCH), while the previous entry is used for the verb ほる (DIG). You can remember this easily by associating扌 with the action and 土 with the object. Because 堀 is used only for the word ほり, it has no on-yomi.

封.mnemonic: Here we observe an outstretched arm (寸) applying two lumps of sticky earth (土) to SEAL an envelope (see V2 of the next entry). Associate M2 ENFEOFF with M1 SEAL through association with the historical process of Enclosure, which “sealed” off common lands so as to turn them into private property.

筒.mnemonic: When 同 appears under ⺮, visualize it as a cross-sectional view of an insulated TUBE (made of bamboo, of course). Also, make an effort to remember that 筒 (トウ) is the only character based on 同 that is not pronounced

管.mnemonic: Bamboo (⺮) government official (官): associate this combination with municipally operated utilities involving bamboo pipes, such as sewerage and water. This should allow you to remember M1 PIPE, as well as M2 EXERCISE CONTROL, from the idea of governmental control over what passes through the pipes.

棺.mnemonic: Every government official (官) is allotted one tree (木) for his COFFIN.

轄.mnemonic: Picking up from 管 1839, we find here another domain in which people expect the government to step in and EXERCISE JURISDICTION: situations when cars (車) cause harm (害).

洞.mnemonic: Here visualize 同 as the door to a CAVE, worn out of a hill over many eons by little drops of water (氵).

窟.mnemonic: A hole/cave (穴) which can only be entered by bending (屈) over: CAVE.

淫.mnemonic: S4-7 is a variant of 爪 claw. We thus observe the courtier (壬) doing something LEWD with his claw to produce a fluid (氵).

妊.mnemonic: At 任 we saw that the role of the man courtier was to be ENTRUSTED with certain duties or OFFICES. By contrast, the role of the woman courtier (妊, i.e., the courtesan) is to BECOME PREGNANT.

唇.mnemonic: A dragon (辰) above a mouth (□): picture this as a long mustache snaking across a man's upper LIP.

辱.mnemonic: Visualize HUMILIATING the dragon (辰) by picking it up and holding it in the air with a single outstretched arm (寸).辱 is the only kanji in this course with the reading ジョク, which can therefore be linked with the meaning HUMILIATE through the mnemonic phrase "making a joke out of someone."

襲.mnemonic: 龍 is the old form of 竜 0507 DRAGON, but here focus instead on its many layers. See 衣 as a man holding out his arms, trying to withstand layer upon layer of bombs dropped from above in an air RAID. With better fortune but no less burden, he can also be seen bearing layer upon layer of material goods, bequeathed from above by a wealthy parent: INHERIT.

伏.mnemonic: Here imagine a man (亻) commanding his dog (犬) to lie down: PROSTRATE.

吠.mnemonic: Dog(犬) mouth (口): HOWL/bark. The reading ほえる (吠える, howl) sounds like “howl.”

噛.mnemonic: Now that we have learned the kanji for “bark,” let us learn the one for BITE, which we write as a mouth (口) that exposes its teeth (歯) so as to cut into something.

班.mnemonic: Here interpret S5-6 as a variant of I] cut. We thus obtain cutting or dividing gems (王). To associate this image with SQUAD, think of a small band of gem robbers who divide their loot.

斑.mnemonic: Think of 文 as a distinctive SPOT “written” on a gem (王).

輩.mnemonic: See 非 as a pair of chummy FELLOWS boarding a taxi (車) after a night at the pub.

忽.mnemonic: Woolly mammoth (勿) + heart/mind(心). Associate this with animal instinct, and thus with immediate, unthinking action: SUDDENLY; CARELESS.

惚.keywords: FALL IN LOVE WITH, grow senile
惚.mnemonic: Heart(忄) + sudden unthinking action (忽): FALL IN LOVE.

猿.mnemonic: 袁 is familiar to us from 園 0856 and 遠 0857, where the garment had one fewer pleat (note that the reading エン is shared with those two kanji). In this entry, we can ignore soil (土) and simply let the garbed four-legged creature (3) suggest a very smart four-legged creature—indeed, a four-handed one: MONKEY.

哀.mnemonic: This entry should not be confused with 袁 in the previous entry, or with the enclosed portion of 園 0856 and 遠 0857: here, the top portion is not 土 land but the upper part of 衣 garment. Picture a person in mourning dress(衣) with an open-mouthed (口) expression of SORROW.

衰.mnemonic: Only S5 distinguishes this entry from the previous one. Think of it as a wrinkle added to.

衷.mnemonic: It is easy to perceive the meaning INNER HEART if you focus visually on how S5, S6, and S9 come together at the INNER HEART of this character. Now practice writing the last three entries in alternation, recognizing the meaning of each in its distinctive feature.

喪.mnemonic: Visualize as the face of a MOURNING woman, covered by a cloth (衣) veil. A pair of sad eyes stares through the veil, dolefully.

忌.mnemonic: Earlier we learned to see 己 as kneeling self. With 心 to suggest heartfelt emotion, picture 己 as one's kneeling in prayer and MOURNING a deep loss. Associate M2 ABHOR with this person's profound displeasure over the untimely loss.

卓.mnemonic: Visualize two people playing TABLE tennis: S1-2 show a player at the far end of the table; 日 shows a table with a net stretched across the center; and S7-8 show a second player at the near end of the table. Associate M2 PROMINENT with M1 TABLE via the idea of being elevated in stature.

悼.mnemonic: When 卓 appears with 忄, think of people grieving over a deceased person who has been laid upon a table for a memorial service: MOURN. Now practice writing 卓 and 悼 and distinguishing their meanings.

貞.mnemonic: Visualize S1-2 as a CHASTITY clasp fastened to a virgin shell (貝) in order to keep it tightly closed.

偵.mnemonic: Think of 亻 as a SPY dispatched to follow the virgin shell that wears the chastity clasp (貞), just in case anyone should try to remove it. Remembering this idea, practice writing 貞 and 偵 in turn.

覇.mnemonic: 覀 is a box for containing a cattle's leather (革) and meat (月). Think of it as symbolizing man's domination/SUPREMACY over animals. As a shortcut, the same meaning can be recognized in 覀's commanding position above 革 and 月.

覆.mnemonic: Box (西) + return/repeat (復, see 0865). To associate this with M2 OVERTURN, let return suggest “turning over” the box. Now imagine turning over the box to CONCEAL something beneath it. Make an effort to remember that the next entry is the only one containing 复 that is not pronounced フク.

履.mnemonic: Door (尸) + return/repeat (復). Let this remind you of a repetitive action that takes place in a doorway: PUT ON FOOTWEAR. You might think of “repeating” the action once for each foot, or repeating it every time you go out the door. Associate PUT ON FOOTWEAR with FULFILL via the idea of “filling someone's shoes.”

属.mnemonic: 禹 resembles 風 WIND, but for the sake of learning the kanji in which it appears, you are better off simply visualizing it as a doorman (S4 is his cap)—that is, a subordinate who works at the door (尸). Think of 禹 as BELONGING TO the house or firm represented by the door, in the sense of hiring out his services exclusively to it.

嘱.mnemonic: Now see the mouth (口) of a superior at the left issuing directives to the subordinate (door-man) at the right: CHARGE WITH.

偶.mnemonic: See 禺 as a monkey (not to be confused with 禹 above). Its head and body frame are obvious enough, but seeing its tail in S10-11 takes a little more imagination. Now imagine the man (亻) and monkey (禺) as a kind of odd COUPLE, brought together by CHANCE despite their glaring differences.

隅.mnemonic: Picture the monkey (禺) swinging and knuckling its way around every NOOK and cranny of the hills (阝).

隙.mnemonic: Visualize the narrow waist point in the middle of 阝 as a small opening (i.e., a small CREVICE or space) in the hills. 小 at the top and bottom emphasize the smallness of the opening, while 日 refers to the sunlight passing through it.

遇.mnemonic: Here we observe the monkey (禺) driving out on his truck (辶) to receive a guest (the kanji refers generally to the TREATMENT one shows to others). If you think of the monkey running into his guest somewhere along the road, it should be easy to remember M2 ENCOUNTER. Be careful to distinguish this kanji from 迎 1139 WELCOME.

愚.mnemonic: Monkey (禺)'s mind (心): FOOLISH. Now note that all the kanji containing 禺 are read グウ、 except the present entry, which is read グ. As always, take care to remember the exception: this one is FOOLISH for missing the pattern set by the others. Take a moment to practice writing and distinguishing this set of four kanji based on 禺.

曹.mnemonic: Think of this as the insignia on the uniform of a SERGEANT. Do not confuse the upper por- tion with 曲 0503. The next two entries incorporate 曹 and follow its on-yomi.

遭.mnemonic: Imagine that the sergeant (曹), as he drives along in his truck (辶), comes upon someone or something unexpectedly: MEET WITH/encounter. In comparison with 逢う(あう, meet with, see, encounter; 1379) and 遇う(あう, encounter, come across; 1877), 遭う(あう) more often refers to encountering some kind of misfortune.

槽.mnemonic: Sergeant (曹) bathing in a wooden (木) TUB in the officers' club.

妨.mnemonic: Review  0174. Here, 方 deliberately HINDERS/obstructs other men from approaching the woman (女).

坊.mnemonic: Recall the image of 方 as a person running. With 土, imagine 方 as a little boy, intimately familiar to you, running freely about your grounds: SONNY BOY. The reading ボウ sounds like BOY. Practice writing this kanji along with 防 0174, 訪 0454, 紡 0835, and 妨 1882, testing yourself on their meanings.

傍.mnemonic: Our three most important graphemes for person, arranged one BESIDE the other. Note that 旁, unlisted by itself, is the kanji for tsukuri (the right-hand, usually sound-bearing component of a kanji).

於.mnemonic: Here 方 implies direction or locality. The element at the right shows the exact position where two items (S7-8) are located. Think of these two items as being located AT that position (i.e., in that place or on that spot.) Note that though 於 appears in the word 於いて (おいて), there is no such word as 於く(おく).

房.mnemonic: Person running (方) through a doorway (戸) into a CHAMBER. To remember M2 TUFT/tassel, you might imagine that there are tassels hanging from the top of the doorway, which brush the person's head as he runs through it.

扇.mnemonic: Like doors (戸) and birds' wings (羽), a FAN is a broad, flat object that turns or flaps.

扉.mnemonic: 戸 depicts a doorframe, and 非 a pair of doors hinged at both sides of the doorway and joining in the middle, like the two-directional doors of a café or old-fashioned saloon: HINGED DOOR.

雇.mnemonic: Picture a miniature hotel that EMPLOYS a small bird (佳) as a door(戸)man.

顧.mnemonic: One's head (頁), i.e., memory, LOOKING BACK ON one's days as a doorman (雁, see previous entry).

屑.mnemonic: Recall from 尾 0488 and 屈 1834 that 戸 can sometimes mean buttocks. The present entry thus depicts fragments(肖) stuck to buttocks: SCRAPS/scum. 肖 is interchangeable with the image that appears under 尸 here.

糞.mnemonic: Rice (米) goes in the top, and something different(異) comes out the bottom: DROPPINGS/shit. A related and even more intuitive character, not introduced in this course, is 屎 (on reading: シ; kun reading: <そ). It combines with the next entry in the word 屎尿 (しにょう、human waste).

尿.mnemonic: Water (水) being excreted from the area below the buttocks (尸): URINE.

泌.mnemonic: Liquid (氵) + without fail (必). Together these components suggest the inevitability of certain bodily functions producing fluid discharge: SECRETE.

尻.mnemonic: If a man counts the orifices in his body starting from his eyes and working downward and front to back, the ninth and final orifice he will count is his anus. Thus buttocks (尸) and nine (九) signify BUTTOCKS.

炉.mnemonic: Fire (火) behind a door (戸): FURNACE.

窯.mnemonic: See here not as a sheep but as a baking rack inside a KILN, with two ceramic pieces stacked on top. 穴 hole/cave suggests an open chamber, heated by 灬 fire.

釜.mnemonic: Visualize as an IRON POT that hangs from a pair of wires (金 suggests metal).

爺.mnemonic: See the lower portion as a variation on 那, suggesting husband (from 旦那 [だんな]). Above the husband is 父, suggesting a still higher father figure: OLD MAN/grandpa.

窪.mnemonic: Water (氵) dripping into a cave (穴), eroding layers of earth (土): SINK/cavity.

佳.mnemonic: Man (亻) carefully piling earth (土) into a perfectly uniform mound: FINE/beautiful.

涯.mnemonic: Picture this as the far side of the ocean, the place where the seawater (氵) finally breaks against cliffs (厂) of piled earth (土): FAR END/outer limits.

暇.mnemonic: First, let 日 suggest day. Then, in S5-9, find the letter "o" followed by a "double-f" suggesting the English word "off." Day off = FREE TIME. Note the differences between 艮 and

霞.mnemonic: In the next five entries, 雨 refers generally to atmospheric moisture. Because this entry means MIST, we should simply let 艮 visually represent densely concentrated water droplets. Note how the numerous short horizontal strokes on both sides of 艮 seem to replicate the water droplets in 雨 (S5-8).

雰.mnemonic: Minutely divided (分) raindrops (雨), referring to the "vapor" (Greek: atmos) that fills the air:

霧.mnemonic: Review 務 0687. The present entry refers to a thick concentration of atmospheric moisture (雨)—so thick one must strike (父) with plows (力) and halberds (矛) to make one's way through it: FOG.

露.mnemonic: Atmospheric moisture (雨) condensing on the road (路): DEW. Associate this with M2 EXPOSE via the idea of being EXPOSED to the elements. Note that this character is also used phonetically for ロ, as in V5.

霜.mnemonic: Atmospheric moisture (雨) congealing on tree (木) tops and eye (目)lashes: FROST.

箱.mnemonic: Here 竹 suggests a kind of instrument. Ignore 相 MUTUAL, and instead let 木 suggest wooden, and 目 a chest of drawers: BOX.

籍.mnemonic: Here 竹 suggests keeping records. With 耒 tiller (introduced back at 耕 1643) and 昔 old, it refers to old records dating back to when your family was engaged in agriculture: family REGISTER.

貫.mnemonic: The top portion of this kanji resembles 田, except that the crossing stroke PENETRATES/ pierces through the sides (it is actually based on the simplified version of 母 used in 每 0105, etc.; note how this is written differently from 田 0020). Focus visually on S4, and imagine a thread piercing through shells (貝) to make a shell necklace.

慣.mnemonic: Suggests ways of thinking and behaving that have deeply penetrated (貫) your heart/mind (忄): HABITUAL PRACTICES.

頂.mnemonic: Review 頁 0156, then 訂 1024 and 打 1025. Here, "nail (丁) + head (頁)" suggests the head or topmost part of a nail-think of this as its SUMMIT. You can also write this kanji to communicate that you RECEIVE HUMBLY, for with it you convey that you receive something as if it were placed upon your head.

戴.mnemonic: Like the last entry, this means RECEIVE HUMBLY and suggests having something placed upon one's head. Here see 異 humbly having something placed upon his head by 戈, which we saw earlier at 裁 1317-裁 1319. We might imagine that he is being crowned with the “Order of the Spear” (戈). An on-yomi compound for タイ appears at 冠 1969.

項.mnemonic: See 工 as a scroll that has been unfurled vertically: S1 and S3 are the rods at each end, and S2 is the unfurled scroll. See 頁 head holding the scroll, examining the individual CLAUSES written on it. Recall that though 頁 appears at the right, it is a semantic element, so use the hen form as your phonetic clue (here, 工、コウ)

頃.mnemonic: This character usually refers to a TIME or period in the past. Picture 匕 as a small child, and see the head (頁) looking back at the TIME when it was small. M2 ABOUT relates with M1 TIME in that it refers to an approximate time.

傾.mnemonic: Here focus on little 匕, trapped between 亻 and 頁. It must choose which one toward which to INCLINE (it chooses 頁).

頑.mnemonic: 元 0136 suggests a firm basis or origin. Together with頁, it indicates a head that is STUBBORNLY rooted in its original idea.

頒.mnemonic: Divide(分) by heads (頁); in other words, distribute evenly to all individuals: DISTRIBUTE WIDELY.

頓.mnemonic: Review 屯 1100. In the present entry, the stationed troops (屯) SUDDENLY come face-to-face (i.e., head-to-head, 頁) with enemy forces.

顕.mnemonic: Here we observe the sun (日) shining its rays directly down (k) upon something, right before one's head (頁): MANIFEST. Note the similarity with 湿 0200.

領.mnemonic: Here think of 頁 as a head of state, issuing commands (令) over the lands under his or her jurisdiction: DOMINION. The strong verticality of S5 (in typical typefaces) emphasizes the head's authoritative top-down control.

頻.mnemonic: Walk (歩) + head (頁): Imagine a person or animal of your choosing walking REPEATEDLY on top of your head. Hear the trot-trot-trot of the frequently REPEATED steps atop your head: ひんぴん、ひんぴん、ひんぴん... (as in the compound 頻々と [ひんぴんと, frequently; in rapid succession]).

捗.mnemonic: Refers to MAKING PROGRESS in one's work: let 扌 suggest working with one's hands, and 步 (walk) suggest forward progress. Note that the walk portion of this kanji uses the old form of 歩(步, which has one fewer stroke). This kanji was not officially standardized with 歩 when it was added to the Joyo list.

順.mnemonic: S4, the head stroke at the top of 頁, also sits near the top of 川 river here, and should be seen as the river's head or source. Let the river's direct downward flow suggest the definite ORDER a river must follow (i.e., OBEY), from its head (S4) straight down to its mouth.

馴.mnemonic: A horse (馬) rides as smoothly as a flowing river (川) once it gets used to being ridden: BECOME TAME.

訓.mnemonic: Picture words (言) of INSTRUCTION “streaming (川)” into the young, i.e., being imbued.

須.mnemonic: See 彡 as the lines of vision coming down from the head (頁) toward an object below it: an object that it MUST have. The direct, intent lines of vision indicate that the head looks upon a certain object as an absolute necessity.

額.mnemonic: Guest (客) head (頁): let this suggest the AMOUNT (of money) charged per head to guests at an inn. This kanji's original meaning was FOREHEAD, so you might think of the front-desk clerk counting guests' FOREHEADS to calculate their bill. Associate M2 PICTURE FRAME with the rectangular shape of the FOREHEAD.

頼.mnemonic: Here picture the bundle (束) as a kind of pillow, which the head (頁) lies on.

瀬.mnemonic: Associate relying on (頼) water (氵) with stretches of a nautical journey where one's safety is particularly reliant on the water's mercy: SHALLOWS/rapids.

峡.mnemonic: Distinguish 夹 from 来 0274 COME. See its two horizontal strokes (S4 and S7 here) as closing in on the two short strokes (丷) and pinching them any tighter and they'll be crushed. With 山, this suggests a narrow canyon pinched between two mountains: a GORGE.

狭.mnemonic: The constrained space between the two pinching (夹) horizontal strokes (ヽ) is so NARROW that even a dog() gets pinched. Note that all four kanji based on 夹 are pronounced キョウ.

挟.mnemonic: See the hand(扌) pinching (夹) the two short strokes (ヽ), i.e., HOLDING them BETWEEN its fingers. Note the traditional form for this entry and the two before it. The old form夹 still appears in the next entry, which was not officially standardized with 峡,狭, and 挟 when it was added to the Joyo list.

頰.mnemonic: The CHEEKS are the part of the head (頁) that people pinch (夹). However, 頰 is probably easiest to recognize simply by seeing S2-3 and S4-5 as dimpled CHEEKS.

顎.mnemonic: A head (頁) with a prominent JAW/chin, clearly visible in 䫟: see S1-6 as two eyes, S7-8 as lips, and the top part of S9 as the JAW/chin (the bottom part of S9 shows the neck). There are numerous kanji based on 䫟 that are not listed in this book (諤 TELL IT LIKE IT IS, 鰐 ALLIGATOR, 齶 JAW, 愕 SURPRISED); the last of these appears in a sample compound at 驚 0807.

煩.mnemonic: Focus visually on S2, a flame leaping up from the fire (火) right toward the head stroke (at the top of 頁), irritating it. See the flame getting altogether too close, VEXING the head.

患.mnemonic: Skewered (串) heart (organ) (心): AFFECTED BY DISEASE.

疾.mnemonic: Suggests an illness ( ) shooting through the body as swiftly as an arrow (矢): DISEASE; FAST.

痴.mnemonic: Illness (广) and knowledge (知) together suggest cognitive impairment: STUPIDITY. Think of M2 INFATUATED as “STUPID for someone.”

疫.mnemonic: Illness (广) advancing as swiftly and destructively as a lance (殳): EPIDEMIC.

痢.mnemonic: Recall from 0412 that 利く (きく) means “work (well), function (properly).” Here 广 suggests a certain bodily function working too well: DIARRHEA. The on-yomi follows 利 (リ).

痘.mnemonic: An illness (广) that causes pea (豆)-sized pustules: SMALLPOX.

瘍.mnemonic: An illness (广) that is difficult (易) to cure: ULCER.

癌.mnemonic: In combination with disease (广), 吅 suggests a growing mountain (山) of self-replicating CANCER cells (品).

痩.mnemonic: Note 叟 in the traditional form, which we saw earlier at 捜 1527. Both it and the simplified form, shown in the head character, can be visualized as a backbone and ribs, with a pair of crossed legs beneath them. In this entry, then, we observe an illness (广) making a person's ribs visible-the illness of BECOMING THIN.

疲.mnemonic: Illness (广) + skin (皮): this does not refer to skin disease, but rather to TIREDNESS. One way to remember this is to think of TIREDNESS as causing certain changes in the color and texture of the skin, such as "bags under the eyes."

被.keywords: BE SUBJECTED TO, be covered in
被.mnemonic: Skin (皮) being covered in clothing(ネ). Associate the physical state of being covered in something with the abstract state of BEING SUBJECTED TO something.

披.mnemonic: Picture the hand (扌) OPENING OUT so as to reveal its skin (皮, i.e., that of its palm).

抜.mnemonic: Here imagine a friend (友)'s hand (扌) PULLING one OUT of a precarious or embarrassing situation. M2 STAND OUT is an extended meaning.

控.mnemonic: Review 空 0398. In the present entry, imagine a suicidal person standing on an exposed beam, threatening to jump. You reach out with your hand (扌) to HOLD him BACK. This kanji can also refer to taking notes, from the idea of "holding onto" something that has been said, rather than letting it disappear forever.

扶.mnemonic: A husband (夫) lending a hand (扌), i.e., LENDING SUPPORT TO.

抹.mnemonic: Hand (扌) bringing something to an end (末): WIPE/erase. As a visual shortcut, you can see the strip between S4 and S5 as a horizontal swath the hand makes across a chalkboard with an eraser. Now take a moment to make sure you can distinguish this entry from the previous one.

拓.mnemonic: A hand (扌) removing a stone (石): OPEN UP (farmland or new frontiers).

拷.mnemonic: This character is dominated by a long and menacingly pointy diagonal stroke (S7). Imagine that it is the knife of a cruel inquisitor, which he threatens to use to puncture the skin of a heretic's hand (扌), and to drive right through its bones into the wooden table of the inquisition room: TORTURE.

楼.mnemonic: Once harvested, field grains must be stored high above the ground to keep them out of the reach of animals. In this entry, visualize a woman (女) storing rice (米) high atop a towering wooden (木) structure: TALL BUILDING.

壇.mnemonic: Visualize 亶 as a rostrum or PLATFORM, built on an earth (土) foundation.

塔.mnemonic: Visualize 荅 as a communications tower: 合 represents the tower structure, while + represents the antennas on its roof. The present entry adds 土 to suggest a deep and sturdy foundation, and means TOWER/pagoda.

搭.mnemonic: Here, visualize the hand (扌) LOADING the antennas (+) ON BOARD the tower(荅). Remembering this idea, practice writing 塔 and 搭 in turn, and learn to associate their meanings with the variable element.

寡.mnemonic: It is useful to associate this kanji with a WIDOW's poverty. Picture S4-9 (like百0016 HUNDRED with an extra zero) as her last thousand dollars, which she carefully stores on a special covered () shelf (S10), dividing (分) it into tiny sums for her expenses. Thus seen, the kanji represents not only WIDOW, but also FEW.

賓.mnemonic: Visualize S4-8 as a uniformed doorman standing at the entrance to a well-to-do family's house (). S4 shows his doorman's cap, S6-7 his epaulets, and S8 his arm pointing toward our left, solicitously pointing the way for the family's wealthy GUEST (貝). This kanji is easily identified by the distinctive image of the welcoming doorman's arm.

飾.mnemonic: Earlier we learned to visualize as a person holding out an object (e.g., see 施 0571, 旗 0573, and乞1805). Here, see holding out a cloth (巾) and placing it over a dining () table: DECORATE.

飽.mnemonic: Here 包 wrap suggests a filled sack. Eat (食) + filled sack: SATIATED. Recall that all kanji incorporating包 are pronounced ホウ.

餓.mnemonic: So hungry, one would eat (食) oneself (我): STARVING. The on-yomi compound to memorize appears in the next entry.

飢.mnemonic: So hungry, one would eat (食) the table (凡): STARVING.

冗.mnemonic: Recall that 凡 can also mean tablecloth. Here, we observe a covering (冖) placed over a tablecloth: REDUNDANT. The on-yomi compound to memorize appears at 談 1977.

冠.mnemonic: Picture the outstretched arm (寸) placing a CROWN (S3) upon someone's head (S4). rein- forces the meaning by suggesting covering, and CROWNS the whole affair for good measure. Being mindful that a CROWN is a covering and not a roof will help you remember that it is written with not.

離.mnemonic: Recall 凶 0296 EVIL MISFORTUNE. Now because the lower part of 离 resembles 内 (うち) (which can refer to one's own home or workplace), we can associate it with a home or work- place that has experienced evil misfortune. Think of the small bird (隹) deciding to SEPARATE himself from such a place.

胸.mnemonic: In the coming series of kanji, 月 will be used in the sense of body part. Here, 匈 suggests the body part wherein an elephant (勹) stores up memories of heart-rending misfortune (凶): his CHEST.

悩.mnemonic: At 桜 1249 we visualized as "falling blossoms." Here, visualize it as "falling into misfortune" (凶), and imagine how this must cause the heart/mind (忄) to SUFFER.

脳.mnemonic: In the strict, physiological sense, the body part (月) directly affected by "falling into misfortune" (see previous entry) is the BRAIN. Practice writing this and 恼, learning to associate SUFFERING (a matter of the spirit) with ↑, and BRAIN (a physical organ) with 月.

臓.mnemonic: Body parts (月) stored inside the storehouse (蔵), i.e., INTERNAL ORGANS.

胃.mnemonic: To remember this kanji, imagine food going into the head (田) and down into a body part (月) located below it: the STOMACH.

談.mnemonic: Words (言) by the flames (炎) of the campfire: TALK/converse.

淡.mnemonic: Water (氵) falling on flames (炎), making them LIGHT/faint.

災.mnemonic: Fire (火) and smoke (<<<, just this time): NATURAL CALAMITY.

肝.mnemonic: Body part (月) for “drying" (干) out (i.e., detoxifying) the bloodstream: LIVER.

肺.mnemonic: 月 suggests body part. Ignore city/market, and instead see 市 as a picture of two pulmonary lobes, framed by a throat (S5), collarbones (S6), and a windpipe (S9): LUNGS. This entry is the only one breaking the rule that kanji with 市 are pronounced シ.

胆.mnemonic: Straying for a moment from our focus at this point in the course, interpret月here as moon, not body part. With旦, it tells us a story of one morning when the moon had the gall to stay out after dawn: GALLBLADDER/gall.

腺.mnemonic: 月 body part + 泉 fountain/spring: GLAND. The on-yomi follows 泉 0207 and 線 0210.

胞.mnemonic: Body part(月) + wrap (包): MEMBRANOUS SAC.

腸.mnemonic: Let “body part (月) + difficult (易)” suggest INTESTINAL discomfort.

胎.mnemonic: Body part (月) that provides a “platform” (台) for the development of a FETUS: the WOMB.

腰.mnemonic: When we learned 要 0547, we pictured a woman weighed down by a heavy box. The present entry refers to the body part(月) that the box causes to bend: the WAIST.

肘.mnemonic: The body part(月) involved in producing an outstretched arm (寸): ELBOW.

膝.mnemonic: Again 月 suggests body part. Back at 漆 1002, we visualized 黍 as splashing drops of sap. Here, let the lower portion suggest splashing drops of “water (水) on the KNEE,” being drained. To distinguish 膝 (ひざ, knee; lap) from 肘 (ひじ, elbow), it is helpful to associate the ざ of ひざ with 座 (ざ, seat), and thus with the lower part of the body.

股.mnemonic: 月 means body part, and both 几 and 又 have CROTCH-like shapes. Therefore, ignore 殳 lance and instead perceive the meaning CROTCH directly from these shapes.

肢.mnemonic: Review the first part of the annotation for 支 0373. This should allow you to perceive in the present entry a branch-like body part (月), or LIMB.

胴.mnemonic: When 同 appears next to 月, visualize it as the rectangular shape of a human torso, housing a couple of internal organs: TRUNK/torso.

脇.mnemonic: At 脅 1496 we visualized three powerful (劦) predators threatening prey. Here, visualize a body part (月) emitting an overpowering stench: ARMPIT. M2 ASIDE is an extended meaning.

脂.mnemonic: If 旨 0931 refers to the essence or substance of something, here it must refer to the “essence of meat (月),” that is, something one always finds when one cuts into it: FAT.

詣.mnemonic: Let “words (言) + essence (旨)” suggest a worshipper's speaking his true feelings to God, as in a heartfelt prayer or confession: VISIT A TEMPLE. This kanji is the one exception to the rule that kanji containing 旨 have the on reading シ.

肪.mnemonic: A slab of meat (月) with a strip of FAT on one side (方).

肌.mnemonic: Tablecloth (几) for the body (月): SKIN.

膚.mnemonic: Tiger (E, review 虎 0912 if necessary) + stomach (胃). To associate this with SKIN, we might imagine removing a tiger's stomach and other viscera, in order to take home only its SKIN.

慮.mnemonic: Paint a picture in your mind's eye of a tiger (E) thinking (思), contemplating whether to initiate a chase or wait for a better opportunity: CONSIDER.

虐.mnemonic: Picture S7-9 as the tiger (E)'s claw, which he CRUELLY uses to maul his victims without the slightest regard for the suffering he causes them.

虞.mnemonic: Typist (呉) entering tiger (E)'s lair: RISK. Note that おそれ is usually written 恐れ (cf. 1633).

劇.mnemonic: Imagine a sword (刂)-fighting DRAMA featuring a tiger (E) and a pig (豕).

虚.mnemonic: Imagine entering the tiger (E)'s lair and finding nothing but a few drops of water dripping from the ceiling and splashing on the ground (业): the lair is EMPTY. M2 FALSE is a derivative meaning.

勇.mnemonic: Recall pointing forward. Here, picture a man (男) running swiftly forward, full of enthusiasm and courage: BRAVE; in high spirits.

湧.mnemonic: Picture streams of sweat (Y) WELLING UP/gushing out of the high-spirited running man (勇).

戯.mnemonic: False (虛) + spear (戈): throwing a spear for SPORT/play, rather than in actual battle.

繊.mnemonic: From 裁 1317, recall the short man (+) holding a spear (戈): 戈. Here he uses the spear as the framework of a loom (recalling 幾 0470), on which he manipulates FINE thread (糸). A helpful way to remember this character is to visualize 业 as extremely FINE FIBERS stretched upon the spear-loom.

緻.mnemonic: Thread (糸) + bring about (致, review 0251 if necessary): let this suggest the deliberate process of stretching thread until it becomes FINE.

嘘.mnemonic: Here we observe a mouth (□) speaking a falsity (虚): LIE.

噂.mnemonic: 尊 means HONOR/esteem (see 0802), but depicts an outstretched arm (寸) holding aloft a ceremonial liquor bottle (酋, shown in non-standardized form in the next two entries). Here, the esteemed figures who have taken from the bottle speak gossip and RUMORS from their liquor-loosened mouths (□).

樽.mnemonic: This time, picture the outstretched arm (寸) refilling the ceremonial liquor bottle (酋) from a wooden (木) BARREL.

距.mnemonic: Here we see a leg (足) making a giant (巨) stride, i.e., covering a great DISTANCE. Note that both characters incorporating 巨 follow its on reading, キョ.

拒.mnemonic: Here we observe the hand (扌) of a person REFUSING/rejecting an offer from a giant (巨), or, if you prefer, from the Tokyo Giants (巨人 [きょじん]).

鼓.mnemonic: Recall the image of 支 0373 as a hand holding up a branch (支). Now imagine the hand beating the branch against the drum at the left (壴, introduced back at 喜 ).

樹.mnemonic: Recall from 喜 1212 that 豆 is a drum that stands on its side. Here picture the outstretched arm (寸) standing up the drum this way. With 木 tree, this provides an intuitive image for STANDING TREE—i.e., a tree that has not been cut down.

膨.mnemonic: Flesh (月) fully stretched out like the skin of a drum (豆). S14-16 emphasize the outward expansion: EXPAND.

脹.mnemonic: Flesh (月) growing “longer” (長), i.e., SWELLING. Removed from the Joyo list in 2010.

張.mnemonic: A bow(弓) being stretched to the fullest possible length (長): SPREAD/STRETCH. Note that kanji with the phonetic component 長 are read チョウ.

帳.mnemonic: “Long(長) cloth (巾)” easily suggests this kanji's original meaning, curtain. Later borrowed to denote a long scroll of paper, this kanji now usually refers to some kind of NOTEBOOK.

腫.mnemonic: Flesh (月) + pile on top of (重): TUMOR/swelling. 脹

肥.mnemonic: 月 and 巴 are similar forms, showing two boxes at the top with a tail trailing downward. The main difference is that in 巴 the boxes are arranged side-to-side, FATTENING it. To easily remember this character, see 巴 as a kind of FATTENED variation on 月.

把.mnemonic: Visualize the hand (扌) GRIPPING 巴 at its bottom-left corner, which makes a perfect handle for a vise-like GRIP.

誇.mnemonic: We have seen S12-13 in 巧1047, etc. Here see it, and the stroke above it, as a kind of ladder climbed by 大 big, representing the idea of growing too big, as in “too big for one’s boots.” The whole kanji, then, suggests “talk(言) too big,” or BOAST.

覧.mnemonic: At 臨 0855 we learned to see as a forward gaze, emphasized here by the stroke that follows below it. With 見 to emphasize the same idea, see the retainer (臣) LOOKING OVER/ viewing.

監.mnemonic: (Continuing from the previous entry) Here the retainer keeps watch over a plate (皿): OVERSEE.

鑑.mnemonic: In the next four entries, 監 will suggest keeping watch over or looking to. This entry indicates a kind of official record or standard (recorded on 金 metal) that the retainer looks to (i.e., REFERS TO) in order to APPRAISE or identify something.

艦.mnemonic: Boat(舟) + keep watch over (監): WARSHIP.

濫.mnemonic: Here picture the retainer in an observation tower, keeping watch over (監) rising flood waters (氵): EXCESSIVE. 濫 is interchangeable with 乱 in compounds for which the latter means “excessive.”

藍.mnemonic: Here picture the retainer keeping watch over(監) a plant(艹) of a color so beautiful that he can't take his eyes off it: INDIGO. Now practice writing the last five entries in alternation, learning to determine their meanings from the variable component.

賢.mnemonic: In the next four entries, the retainer (臣) serves his master not with his eye, but with his hand (又). In this entry, he WISELY increases his master's fortune by stashing away shells (貝, i.e., money).

腎.mnemonic: Eager to save his master's life, the retainer (臣) hands (又) him a spare body part (月): one of his KIDNEYS.

堅.mnemonic: Once more proving his all-around utility, the retainer (臣) uses his hand (又) to solidify the earth (土) foundation of his master's home: FIRM/solid.

緊.mnemonic: Here the retainer (臣) uses his hand (又) to TIGHTEN a loose cord (糸). M2 EXIGENT is an extended meaning. Now practice writing the last four entries in alternation, and distinguishing their meanings based on the grapheme that appears at the bottom.

勃.mnemonic: Interpret 孛 as a child (子) hiding under the ground (土, which here is in fact 十 and Ↄ). Now picture the child SUDDENLY RISING from his underground hiding place and taking up the plow (力).

励.mnemonic: Here picture ten thousand (万) workers emerging from a tunnel inside a cliff (广), pushing the plows (力) with which they have been WORKING HARD to bore the tunnel. This character can also be used to express the idea of urging people on to such laborious efforts.

栃.mnemonic: This kanji and the next one were among those added to the Joyo list for the specific reason that they are used in names of prefectures. Because they are used almost exclusively in these names (V1 in both entries), your time is better spent learning to read the names than learning these kanji for their own sake.

茨.mnemonic: (See previous entry) As with 恣 1454, the form used here differs slightly from 次, but we can safely ignore this difference.

羨.mnemonic: Picture the sheep (羊) coveting his neighbor's (i.e., the next person's) possessions: ENVIOUS.

歳.mnemonic: This kanji is used as the suffix "-YEARS OLD," though it is often replaced in this role by the homophonous 才. It indicates the year-by-year aging process by placing 小 at the bottom (for childhood), 戊 above that (for adulthood, recalling 成人 [せいじん, adult]), and finally 止 at the very top, for the end of one's YEARS.

戚.mnemonic: Interpret 束 (not to be confused with 歩) as an image of older (上) and younger (小) relatives together. With 戊 guided spear, it suggests the passing on of duties from one generation to another within a KIN group. To distinguish from 歳 above: while one's aging process eventually stops (上), one's KIN group does not (no 止).

叔.mnemonic: Because this kanji refers to both uncles and aunts that are younger than one's parent, we use "YOUNGER SIBLING OF PARENT" as its keyword. However, to refer to it more easily when it appears inside the three kanji that follow, we'll use uncle as the grapheme name. In this entry, we have "relative (未) who lends you a hand (又)": uncle/aunt (YOUNGER SIBLING OF PARENT).

淑.mnemonic: Here we add water (氵) to uncle (叔) to suggest an uncle of purity and refinement: GRACEFUL/ refined.

寂.mnemonic: Uncle (叔) by himself at home (宀): LONESOME.

督.mnemonic: Uncle (叔) looking after the children with a watchful eye (日): SUPERVISE; COMMANDER.

奴.mnemonic: Picture this woman (女) as an evil mistress who uses her hand (又) to slap a SLAVE. M2 GUY reflects this kanji's use as an informal way to refer to a male.

努.mnemonic: (Continuing from the previous entry) Slapped by the mistress, the slave (奴) EXERTS himself with the plow (力). Note that the kanji incorporating 奴 follow its on-yomi, ド、怒

怒.mnemonic: Slapped slave (奴)'s heart (心): ANGRY. Do not confuse with the name-use kanji 恕 MAGNANIMITY.

隷.mnemonic: Recall 隶 hand spraying water from hose, introduced at 逮 1608. Now picture 士 military man as a man in position of authority, standing on top of an altar (示, which we might imagine here simply as some kind of raised platform) from which he hoses down his UNDER-LINGS.

款.mnemonic: (Continuing from the previous entry) Now picture the military man (士) standing on the raised platform and reading out (of a wide-open mouth, 欠) the ARTICLES of a treaty of FRIENDLY RELATIONS between himself and his underlings.

殻.mnemonic: Simplify the next two entries by ignoring 士,  冖, and 殳, which are held constant, and focusing on the variable component at the lower left. Since 殼 refers to a grain's HUSK (or a shellfish's shell), while 穀 refers to the GRAIN itself, associate 禾 rice (next entry) with GRAIN,

臼.mnemonic: You have already seen this grapheme in some old forms, including those of 児 0772(兒) and 挿1597(插). For the few modern forms in which it still appears (such as 毀 below), it is sufficient to use 臼 as a visual clue. By itself, it means MORTAR (i.e., grinding stone).

毀.mnemonic: 臼 resembles a BROKEN object, lying on the ground (土). Picture for a moment this object before it was BROKEN, then imagine using this lance (殳) to BREAK it.

廉.mnemonic: "Shelter (广) + combine (兼, see 1006)" suggests sharing a dwelling, an apt image for M2 CHEAP. Associate this with M1 HONEST via the idea of honest, frugal living.

鎌.mnemonic: Combine (兼) two pieces of metal (a blade and a handle) into a SICKLE.

嫌.mnemonic: Women (女), as this character would have it, DISLIKE combining (兼) things, i.e., doing two things at the same time.

謙.mnemonic: Combining (兼) words (言) (i.e., speaking in compressed language) is a sign of HUMILITY.

遜.mnemonic: Picture a grandchild (孫1079) driving a modest truck (辶_): HUMBLE/modest.

亀.mnemonic: The stylized but still recognizable result of what began as a drawing of a TURTLE.

練.mnemonic: Before being simplified, the next two entries contained 柬, not 東, which explains why they are read レン, not トウ. To keep things simple, we will keep using the grapheme meaning all the way through, which in the present entry implies a thorough process of improving thread (糸) or the cloth made from it. Associate this thorough process of improvement with the figurative senses TRAIN or drill.

錬.mnemonic: (Continuing from the previous entry) Here, think of a similarly thoroughgoing process for REFINING metal (金) all the way through. Like the previous entry, this kanji can refer to training people in a skill or discipline.

鍛.mnemonic: Metal (金) + step (段 0521): suggests metal's being FORGED in stages. Visualize the stages in the four horizontal strokes at the left of 段. Like the previous two entries, this kanji can also mean train.

鉱.mnemonic: Metal(金)+ wide (広) suggests the extensive course of a mineral vein: ORE; MINE.

銅.mnemonic: Back at 筒 1838, we visualized 同 as a cross-sectional view of an insulated TUBE. Here, see it as a cross-section of an insulated electrical wire. 金 refers to the metal used for the wire: COPPER.

鉛.mnemonic: Review 船 0669. Here, metal(金) is inserted into a rolling hoop: a LEAD pencil into a pencil sharpener.

銑.mnemonic: PIG IRON is iron at a stage of smelting prior to (先) becoming cast iron or steel. This kanji was removed from the Joyo Kanji List in 2010.

鋼.mnemonic: Metal (金) hard enough to bore through a hill (岡): STEEL.

剛.mnemonic: A sword (刂) hacking through a hill (岡): TOUGH/strong.

綱.mnemonic: Thread (糸) for climbing a hill (岡): ROPE. Associate this with M2 MAIN POINTS via the idea of a central guiding line or principle.

網.mnemonic: Identical to the previous entry, except that mountain (山) is replaced here by dead (亡). Here, visualize S9-10 as two dead mosquitoes caught in a NET. Practice distinguishing 綱 and 網 based on their variable component, and associating that component with the meaning.

縄.mnemonic: Behold a long ROPE (L) with two knots tied in it (田 and 田). Compare the right half of this character with .

鉢.mnemonic: Metal (金) basis (本), i.e., a metal object that supports from below: BOWL.

鎖.mnemonic: Visualize S10 and S11 as links in a metal CHAIN fastened around S9 to secure a valuable shell or, if you prefer, money (貝).

絆.mnemonic: Visualize S7-8 as parts of a rope (糸) strung around the top of S11 to tie a man down: BONDS/fetters.

鍵.mnemonic: Metal (金) + build (建): suggests a metal KEY for opening a building (建物、たてもの).

釘.mnemonic: Metal (金) NAIL (丁, review 訂 1024 if necessary).

錮.mnemonic: LOCKING DOWN firmly(固) with metal(金).

錠.mnemonic: Metal(金) for fixing (定) things in place: LOCK. Also means PILL, which is easy to remember if you think of the round, tablet-like shape of some locks.

綻.mnemonic: Picture the thread (糸) getting fixed (定) in place (i.e., getting caught on something), so that it starts unraveling: COME APART AT THE SEAMS.

鐘.mnemonic: Here we observe a child (童) standing on an adult's shoulders and tolling a large metal (金) BELL. This kanji refers to large bells that toll, not to small bells that jingle or ring (for the latter, use 鈴 2082).

瞳.mnemonic: Let child (童) suggest the smallest part of the eye (目): PUPIL.

憧.mnemonic: YEARNING AFTER with the heart (忄) of a child (童). A sample on-yomi compound appears in the next entry.

憬.mnemonic: A scene (景 1280) that fills one's heart (忄) with longing: YEARN AFTER.

卑.mnemonic: Refers to someone or something that is MEAN or despised. Like 単 0462, it resembles a stick figure with a box head (田) and simple body. See the short diagonal stroke (S7) as the figure's line of vision, pointing down from the head toward some MEAN, lowly thing it looks down on.単

碑.mnemonic: Though we should not carry over the idea of MEAN or despicable from the previous entry, we can visualize 卑 inside this character physically looking down at the stone, for 石 represents a tombstone or other stone MONUMENT placed on the ground. Note that both kanji incorporating 卑 follow its on reading, ヒ.

痺.mnemonic: An illness (+) that, as this character would have it, causes one to be looked down on (卑):

鬼.mnemonic: An appropriately heinous image of a DEMON, this unlovely stick figure with its nose (ム) lopped off.

醜.mnemonic: A demon (鬼), liquored (酉): an UGLY spectacle.

魅.mnemonic: See 未 not yet as a CHARM the demon (鬼) has not yet utilized. See his limb reaching way over to the right (S8), clutching this powerful CHARM, waiting for just the right moment to cast it upon you ... not yet... not yet...

魔.mnemonic: Review 麻 0852 through 暦 0854, which contain important notes regarding **. Here and in two other entries that follow shortly, we return to 広. In this entry, we observe a demon (鬼) on hemp. The drug's effect goes beyond that of liquor (in 醜 2092); indeed, it turns him from a mere DEMON into a devil.

畏.mnemonic: Behold the FEARful image of a man dressed in a flowing cloak (from 衣) with a featureless four-square head (田), resembling a demon (鬼).

刷.mnemonic: Here visualize slicing (刂) a cloth (巾), laying it on a door (尸, used as a flat surface), and then PRINTING a design on it.

擦.mnemonic: Ignore the meaning inspect, and simply see 察 as a very jagged surface. Picture the hand (扌) RUBBING itself up against the serrated, snaggy points along the left side of 察, and imagine the feeling of painful chafing and abrasion.

摩.mnemonic: (Continuing from the previous entry) Now picture 手 RUBBING AGAINST abrasive hemp (麻*), and imagine the same harsh scratching sensation.

磨.mnemonic: Now imagine POLISHING a stone (石) with a hemp (麻*) brush. This character is interchangeable with the previous entry in some compounds.

奉.mnemonic: 夫 evokes an image of a row of small torii gates, as one often sees lined up covering pathways in Shinto shrines (if you haven't seen such a pathway, do an image search for “Fushimi Inari Taisha” or “Fushimi Inari Shrine,” where the most famous of these pathways is located). The association is relevant, for 奉 is always written on these small torii gates, which people or companies DEDICATE to a shrine. See S6-8 as a man holding a new torii gate offering in his outstretched arms, and setting it in place: an ideal image for DEDICATE/offer.

奏.mnemonic: S8-9 are all that differs from the previous entry. There, the vertical S8 suggested the dedicator’s upright body, whereas here, it splits into the two curving strokes 8 and 9. This makes the lower part of the character resemble the upper part in miniature, so that 奏 can be seen as an adult-child duet on the koto: the large diagonal strokes are adult’s hands, PLAYING MUSIC on a full-size koto; the short diagonal strokes represent child’s hands, PLAYING MUSIC on a child-size koto (the horizontal strokes show the strings). Let the point of divergence between 奏 and 奉 suggest the meaning of each character.

泰.mnemonic: With 水 water at the bottom, this entry is a bit easier to distinguish from the previous two. It presents a scene of calming waters under a shelter: TRANQUIL. Do not confuse this entry or the previous one with the name-use kanji 秦, used in reference to the QIN DYNASTY of China and in the Japanese surname Hata.

俸.mnemonic: An offer (奉) made to a man (亻): SALARY.

棒.mnemonic: Offerings (奉) from a tree (木): RODS and sticks!

捧.mnemonic: Remember by association with 奉 2103. 才 reinforces the idea of OFFERING by suggesting the sense of “handing to.”

耐.mnemonic: This is the first time we've encountered 而, not to be confused with 冊. Picture 而 as branching roots. In this entry, we observe roots WITHSTANDING/enduring the strained attempts of an outstretched arm (寸) to pull them out of the ground.

霊.mnemonic: Here let represent “the heavens.” We can interpret the bottom portion as if it were 並 lined up, suggesting the straight, undeviating path to the heavens that SPIRITS take.

濡.mnemonic: In response to the roots' demand (需), water (氵): WET roots.

儒.mnemonic: Confucian philosophy is less concerned with questions of the soul and the afterlife than it is with the problems of humans in this world. This outlook is aptly expressed in the kanji for CONFUCIANISM, which refers to the demands (需) of man (亻). Note that the East Asian terms for Confucianism (V1-2) in fact make no reference to Confucius (孔子, see 1559).

端.mnemonic: This is the only kanji in this course in which 立 appears as a hen. To remember that it means EDGE/extremity, picture the man standing precariously at the EDGE of a mountain (山), holding on for dear life to some exposed tree roots (而).

壱.mnemonic: This kanji belongs to the special set used for writing numbers in bank notes and other legal documents, as a way to prevent people from adding strokes to easily altered characters (such as 一). Here picture a military man (士) who owns only ONE spoon (匕, the one in his mess kit), which he therefore keeps well covered ( 冖).

尼.mnemonic: Picture a BUDDHIST NUN trying to escape from a nunnery by digging a hole under the (locked) door (尸) with a spoon (匕).

泥.mnemonic: (Continuing from the previous entry) In the process of digging her way out of the nunnery, the nun (尼) strikes water (氵), creating MUD. The reading デイ is unique in this course.

漏.mnemonic: Rainwater (雨, 氵) coming through the door (尸): LEAK.

彙.mnemonic: Visualize S1-5 as some kind of device being used to measure fruit trees (果), in an effort to compile systematic information about them, i.e., to CATALOG them.

某.mnemonic: You should usually avoid remembering a kanji's meaning with a memorized phrase. For this entry, however, the definition is itself a phrase (“A CERTAIN”), so you might simply learn the words, “A CERTAIN tree (木) with sweet (甘) nectar.” By using this cryptic phrase, a bee colony avoids identifying the tree, and so keeps the nectar to itself.

謀.mnemonic: (Continuing from the previous entry) Imagine a clandestine SCHEME/plot among the bees to acquire the tree's sweet nectar. In discussing (言) their SCHEME, they maintain strict secrecy regarding the tree's location by referring to it only as “a certain tree with sweet nectar.”

媒.mnemonic: (Continuing from 2121-22) Now picture the worker bees flying back and forth between the certain tree with sweet nectar and their queen (女): MEDIATE.

尉.mnemonic: This kanji can be visualized as the entrance to an OFFICERs' club. Through its doorway 尸, we can see one of the tables inside (here shown as an altar 示). At the right is a doorman with an outstretched arm (寸), showing the OFFICERS in.

慰.mnemonic: When soldiers are killed in battle, the duty of notifying their families falls to an officer(). Here we observe an officer trying his best to CONSOLE a broken heart (心).

酪.mnemonic: Recall that 西 can mean either liquor or ferment. In this entry, we thus obtain “ferment + cabin (各),” suggesting the production of yogurt and cheese in a barn: DAIRY PRODUCTS.

酵.mnemonic: Ferment (酉) + filial piety (孝): picture the child (子) piously FERMENTING liquor for his alcoholic parent to drink.

醤.mnemonic: Your starting point here should be the word しょうゆ (SOY SAUCE), which is easy to remember from its homophony with the English word derived from it, “soy.” You can then recognize this kanji by the presence of 将 0614, which indicates the on reading ショウ, and ferment(西), which refers to the sauce’s fermentation from soybeans.

酢.mnemonic: Liquor (酉) that cuts like a saw (乍): VINEGAR.

酎.mnemonic: Outstretched arm (寸), reaching for a bottle (酉) of SHOCHU.

酌.mnemonic: Picture the elephant (勹) POURING WINE from the liquor bottle (酉) at the left. Visualize the half-empty bottle in S10, which he's tipping just now, decanting a glass of red for his guest.

釣.mnemonic: (Continuing from the previous entry) Here the elephant aims downward with a wire tied to a metal (金) fishhook, angling it (as shown in S11) toward the surface of a pond: ANGLE.

畜.mnemonic: Review 育 RAISE, from which we'll borrow the image of a rearing parent's head and broad shoulders (S1-2). Here it represents a breeder, raising a child (幺) of the fields (田): LIVESTOCK.

蓄.mnemonic: Here we observe the rearing breeder STORING UP grass (++) for his livestock (畜) to eat.

玄.mnemonic: Now we'll leave behind “breeder,” and once again see 一 as a rearing parent. Observe how he shelters his child (幺) from the world, hiding her in deep darkness beneath his broad shoulders: PROFOUND/occult.

眩.mnemonic: Now imagine the child emerging from profound/occult (玄) darkness and suddenly exposing her eyes (日) to bright light: DAZZLING.

呟.mnemonic: Mouth (□) speaking in an occult (玄) manner (i.e., unintelligibly): MUTTERING. Note that all four kanji incorporating 玄 in the phonetic position, including the two that appear a few entries further ahead, follow its on reading, ゲン。咳

囁.mnemonic: Three ears (耳) gather closely around a WHISPERING mouth (□). This easily remembered image represents a class of high stroke-count but intuitive kanji that have become an appeal-ing choice for writers since the invention of keyboard kanji input.

喋.mnemonic: Let 葉 represent 葉 0605 LEAF. Now picture thin, light, fluttering leaves being blown from the mouth (□), symbolizing light, fluent conversation: SPEAK/chat.

喩.mnemonic: 兪 is the old form of 俞 (package of sliced meat), not standardized with 輸 0945, etc. when the present entry was added to the Joyo list. Read both forms interchangeably. Here we observe a mouth (□) LIKENING something metaphorically to sliced meat, perhaps by calling it "the best thing since sliced meat," if you will.

鬱.mnemonic: Illustrates the same point about high stroke count kanji mentioned in 囁 above. Simply associate this kanji's oppressively crowded, dense, confined look with feelings of DEPRESSION and CONGESTION. Use the upper part of as a visual focus for producing these sensations.

弦.keywords: STRING (of a bow or musical instrument)
弦.mnemonic: In the next two entries, I suggest you ignore 玄 profound/occult, and use visual shortcuts instead. Here, visualize S5 as a STRING the child (幺) attaches to the bow.

舷.mnemonic: Here see S8 as the upper edge along the side of the boat (舟): GUNWALE.

舵.mnemonic: Visualize 匕 as a RUDDER protruding from the stern of a boat (舟), and as the helmsman's arm, reaching out to adjust the RUDDER's direction.

幻.mnemonic: Lacking the "ear" stroke (see局0256), 𠂊 is not an elephant, but only the illusion of one. It is only a PHANTOM elephant, a figment of the child (幺)'s imagination.

幽.mnemonic: Two children (幺幺), each hiding deep in the quiet seclusion of a mountain (山) chasm:

幼.mnemonic: Here think of the plow (力) as a tool for cutting. With幺, this suggests a child just now cutting its teeth: VERY YOUNG child.

稚.mnemonic: In the next several entries try to visualize the small bird (隹) performing various actions (or in one case, having an action done to it). In this entry, we observe a small bird carrying rice (禾) home to its CHILD. The readingチ is easy to associate with CHILD.

維.mnemonic: Small bird (隹) carrying thread (糸) FIBERS for holding together its nest.

推.mnemonic: Hand (扌) PUSHING small bird (佳) FORWARD. Noting V4, you might think of it as the same small bird as the one in 進 0191 ADVANCE, now needing a friendly PUSH in order to start advancing. Also means INFER, in the sense of pushing a logical argument forward from evidence to a conclusion.

堆.mnemonic: Small bird (隹) PILING UP earth (土).

椎.mnemonic: Picture the small bird (佳) as a woodpecker, pecking a hole in a CHINQUAPIN tree (木) or, alternatively, in your SPINE.

脊.mnemonic: Picture S3-6 as sets of ribs, surrounding a SPINE (人). 月signals the general category body

雛.mnemonic: A small bird (隹) with a pair of tiny CHICKS, which resemble miniature elephants (勹勹).

誰.mnemonic: Think of 隹 here as a talking parakeet whose cage is placed next to the entrance to a home, where he inquires the name of callers. His vocabulary is limited to a single word (言): WHO?

唯.mnemonic: MERELY a small bird (隹)'s mouth (口) (in size).

鳴.mnemonic: “Bird(鳥)+ mouth (口)” refers to the chirping or CRYING of birds and animals. M2 SOUND is a derivative meaning. Practice distinguishing this entry from the previous one, remembering that the small bird's mouth is the one that implies MERELY.

亥.mnemonic: Visualize a BOAR, its snout pointing up in the air at the top of S4-5, from which its long whiskers trail down and to the left. To refer to the actual creature, use 猪 0217; the present entry is only used in reference to the Chinese horary or zodiac sign of THE BOAR.

刻.mnemonic: [] indicates that the time has come to carve (i.e., ENGRAVE) the boar. Visualize J carving between S4-5. This kanji also means POINT IN TIME, in the sense of precisely sliced segments of time—for example, the segment corresponding to the horary sign of the Boar: 亥の刻 (いのこく, 10 o'clock in the evening).

劾.mnemonic: Recall from 動 0540 and功 1046 the image of 力 powerfully dragging something behind it. Here visualize it dragging the boar out from its hiding place in order to EXPOSE its CRIMES.

核.mnemonic: Picture the boar (亥) eating all the way through to the core of the tree (木), i.e., to its NUCLEUS.

骸.mnemonic: Bones (骨) of a boar (亥)'s corpse: BODY/skeleton. The long strokes 14 and 15 emphasize the image of exposed bones.

咳.mnemonic: Mouth (口) + bristly boar (亥): raspy COUGH.

該.mnemonic: A shortcut to perceiving the meaning CORRESPOND TO in this character is to see the graphemes on left and right as roughly CORRESPONDING TO one another (at least in the head character's handwritten form, in which S1 and S8 are both written diagonally).

診.mnemonic: It is time for 言 to go in for a doctor's checkup. Visualize ∧ as the roof of the doctor's clinic, and 彡 as the doctor's examining successively lower parts of 言's body, as by palpating it or tapping it with a reflex hammer: EXAMINE A PATIENT.

珍.mnemonic: Here interpret 彡 as a hair-like pattern. This kanji thus refers to a gem (王) whose grain is highly unusual in showing a fine, hair-like pattern: RARE gemstone.

瓦.mnemonic: Visualize as a TILE at the corner of a roof. S1 marks the roof's ridge, S2 one of its hips, S3 the eaves, and the bottom of S4 a rain gutter. In the center picture a TILE, marked with a special design (S5) because it occupies the end of the roof's hip. To clarify this, do an image search for 鬼瓦 (おにがわら), preferably in Japanese.

併.mnemonic: Earlier you learned to see 井 as a torii gate. When you see 并, imagine that the two dot strokes at the top are two hands trying to push down the top crosspiece so as to merge it with the second crosspiece. 并 will thus mean put together. In this entry, visualize the man (亻) using his two hands to try to PUT TOGETHER the crosspieces.

瓶.mnemonic: Many traditional roof tiles (瓦) are semicircular in shape. Put together (并) two of these and you get a round jar or BOTTLE. Note the pattern in the traditional form, shared by all the characters in this set based on 并.

屏.mnemonic: Here, see 并 as a bunch of slats put together into a FENCE or folding screen. 戸 indicates the top part of the structure. Since 戸 also means doorway, it further suggests the way a FENCE or folding screen can be swung open.

塀.mnemonic: Earth (土) fence (屏): FENCE/wall. 垣1397,壁1466,堀1836

餅.mnemonic: The next two entries are shown with 食, the old form of 食. They were not standardized with 館 0291, etc. when they were added to the Joyo list. As usual, treat both forms as one and the same. In this entry, 食/食 indicates the general category food, while the top two strokes of 并 depict the way RICE CAKES pop up over a hot fire.

餌.mnemonic: Ears (耳) may not be suitable for human food (食/食), but they are perfectly acceptable as animal FEED, or as BAIT. While we show here the officially listed forms 餅 and 餌, forms using 食 are also accepted, so you needn't worry about having to write the traditional form.

呑.mnemonic: The next three kanji contain not 天 but 夭, whose top stroke is written from right to left. In this entry, visualize the mouth (口) trying to accomplish the very difficult task of SWALLOWING 夭, like a snake trying to gulp down an ostrich egg. Like 飲 0289, 呑 is read のむ, but it refers to SWALLOWING and gulping rather than drinking.

沃.mnemonic: Let the difference between 天 and 天 serve as the visual clue to the meaning of this character. Focusing on the incline of S4, see 夭 as a person tilting a container to pour liquid (氵) nutrients into the land: FERTILE.

妖.mnemonic: Again take your cue from the sloping line of 夭. See 夭 here as a person whose "head" (S4) turns toward the woman (女), caught by the spell of her BEWITCHING beauty.

呪.mnemonic: Older brother (兄)'s mouth (口) uttering a curse/CHARM.

艶.mnemonic: Recall 豊 0513 ABUNDANT. With 色, we have “abundant color” (expressing M1 CHARMING/voluptuous; glossy) or “abundant eros” (expressing M2 ROMANCE).

慈.mnemonic: See S1-3 as a hand facing downward (S3 shows the palm, S1-2 show two knuckles sticking up). Here then, we see a hand holding two young children (玆) to its heart (心): a vivid image of AFFECTION. Note that the three kanji based on 茲 are all pronounced ジ.

滋.mnemonic: Now see liquid (氵) NOURISHING the two young children (玆).

磁.mnemonic: You can feel the magnetism of the stone when you’re close enough to touch it with your own two 兹 stones.

擁.mnemonic: Here we observe the hand (扌) at the left placing itself like a lid (一) over the young(幺) bird.

腐.mnemonic: Meat (肉) distributed to public support recipients by a government office (府 0247): ROTTEN.

芯.mnemonic: Heart (心) of a plant (艹): CORE. As the sample vocabulary indicates, 芯 can refer to the CORE of things besides plants, such as the lead of a pencil, or the wick of a candle. Note that it can always be replaced by 心 0056.

蒔.mnemonic: Plant (艹) + time (時): a time to SOW.

撒.mnemonic: Hand (扌)+ scatter(散 0808): let this suggest SCATTERING with the hands, as one does with seeds or handbills.

撤.mnemonic: You should learn this one in such a way that you can distinguish it from the entries before and after it. Unlike the one before, but like the one after, it contains 育 raise. When 育 appears with 扌, think of a parent's hand WITHDRAWING her child from something in which he has entered. 攵 strike suggests parental discipline.

徹.mnemonic: (Continuing from the previous entry) Here 育 appears with 彳 go, which is our mnemonic clue for the meaning GO THROUGH (with). Unlike in the previous entry, this time the parent does not WITHDRAW the child, but instead lets him GO THROUGH with something. Practice distinguishing the last three entries by their variable elements.

微.mnemonic: As with the previous set of three kanji, the set of three that starts here will require us to focus our attention on the variable component. Ignore 彳, 山, and 攵, which are held constant. Surrounded by these three, we find in this entry a form similar to table/tablecloth, but in fact more closely resembling π pi. We can therefore get a little irrational and use π as a mnemonic clue for SLIGHT/minute, since despite its infinite decimal places, π is, after all, a SLIGHT number. It is easy to associate the reading ビ with “pi” (π).

徴.mnemonic: (Continuing from the previous entry) This time, associate gem (王) with valuables collected by a fiscal LEVY or impost. Unrelatedly, you can associate I's other meaning of spherical object with M2 SIGN, as in a SIGN that one might look for in a crystal ball.

懲.mnemonic: Levying (徵) a stiff penalty upon a heart (心): CHASTISE. As a visual shortcut, you might see the heavy burden of four graphemes upon heart as a kind of CHASTISING punishment upon it. They do seem to be coming down on poor 心 like a ton of bricks.

殆.mnemonic: Picture the platform (台) as an operating table or sickbed, with death (歹) waiting nearby: ALMOST dead. The word 殆ど (ほとんど) is used like “mostly” or “hardly,” in the sense of “ALMOST all...” or “ALMOST no...”

后.mnemonic: Let 口 represent the emperor, in the sense of the “mouthpiece” or public face of the imperial family. See S1-3 as the EMPRESS, faithfully standing behind him.

垢.mnemonic: Now observe how the empress (后) has gotten some soil (土) on the back of her heretofore-immaculate gown, an image that emphasizes this kanji’s meaning, DIRT.

妃.mnemonic: Visualize 己 as a lady-in-waiting kneeling before a married PRINCESS.

姫.mnemonic: 臣 is a retainer assigned to keep ardent young men away from this DAUGHTER OF NOBLE BIRTH.

如.mnemonic: Woman (女)+ mouth (□). This kanji reflects the archaic expectation that a woman is pliantly to “do AS she is told.

茹.mnemonic: (Continuing from the previous entry) Making plants (⺾) more “pliant” so that they will do as (如) they are told: BOIL. Do not confuse with the name-use kanji 茄 EGGPLANT.

婿.mnemonic: A woman (女) carrying broken (疋, i.e., butchered) meat (月). Think of her as a bride carrying her dowry to the bridegroom, i.e., her parents' new SON-IN-LAW.

娘.mnemonic: As this kanji would have it, a woman (女) is good(良) when she is still a GIRL, before the trials of life have made her bitter.

嫁.mnemonic: A woman (女) moving into her husband's home (家): WED A MAN; BRIDE.

稼.mnemonic: Bringing rice (禾) home (家): WORK (for a living).

塚.mnemonic: A pig (豕) covering (^^) himself in a MOUND of soil (土).

豪.mnemonic: S1-5 are the roof and second-story window from 高 0185 TALL. Picture a pig (豕) that truly stands tall: GREAT MAN; MAGNIFICENT. Also used as the kanji abbreviation for Australia (a selected list of kanji abbreviations for countries and regions appears in Appendix 5).

蒙.mnemonic: See this as a pig (豕) lying in the dark, covered () by the grass (++) of the Mongolian steppe: IGNORANCE/darkness. Also used as the kanji abbreviation for Mongolia. Note the extra stroke between 豕 and.

墾.mnemonic: At last we meet 豸, the badger. See S2-3 as his beady eyes and S1 as a stripe along the top of his head. The act of CLEARING LAND FOR FARMING is intuitively illustrated here with an image of clearing new land (土) at the limit/boundary (艮) where the farmer's land ends and the badger's land begins.

懇.mnemonic: (Continuing from the previous entry) This time, rather than crossing the boundary to the badger's land, we cross the boundary to his heart (心), i.e., we become FAMILIAR/intimate with him. Also means EARNEST, from the idea of pursuing something without inhibition or pretense.

貌.mnemonic: At the right, white (白) on top of legs (儿) suggests a white head. We can thus interpret this kanji as a description of a badger (豸)'s APPEARANCE.

逐.mnemonic: Now we return to the more familiar pig (豕). Devise for yourself a memorable plot climaxing in a town's banishing all its pigs. Then picture here a pig being DRIVEN OUT out of town. It is important to picture the pigs being driven out ONE BY ONE, with special attention given to every individual.

遂.mnemonic: This character tells a completely different story, for here we have not simply a pig (豕), but a crack pig commando (see 隊 0586), whom we picture advancing (辶) forward to carry out/ACCOMPLISH his special mission.

墜.mnemonic: Here we observe a party (隊) of pig commandos DROPPING DOWN from the hills toward the earth (土). Compared to the next entry, we should see the commandos plunging rapidly, for 墜 is mostly used in reference to plane crashes and other fatal falls. See them DROP DOWN like rocks with their heavy backpacks.

堕.mnemonic: Here again we see something falling toward the earth (土). However, compared to the last entry's "DROP DOWN," this entry's "DEGENERATE" suggests a more gradual sinking. For this reason, it helps here to see the outstretched hand (न) providing resistance, and slowing the fall to a gradual descent.

随.mnemonic: The image of 有 upon (辶) is a simplification of 適. We'll interpret the simplified form, which suggests having something on the bed of one's truck, as a loaded vehicle. In this entry, the vehicle drives up into the hills (B), while the load FOLLOWS behind.

附.keywords: ATTACH, be attached to, hand over
附.mnemonic: This kanji was formerly used for the intransitive verb つく, while 付 was used for the transitive つける. They have since come to be used indistinctly, and the present entry has largely fallen out of use. On the infrequent occasions when you encounter 附, interpret it the same way you would 付: ATTACH/be attached to/hand over.

髄.mnemonic: (Continuing from 随 2213) Picture the loaded vehicle (at the right) as a surgeon's loaded needle, advancing forward toward the center of a bone (骨): MARROW.
